[[File:Cherkizovskaya, policemans preparing to guard a footbal stadium (Черкизовская, милиционеры, готовящиеся охранять стадион во время футбольного матча) (5380196105).jpg|thumb|400px|[[Law enforcement in Russia|Russian police]] on a street in [[Cherkizovskaya]], [[Moscow]].]] '''Crime in Russia''' is combated by the [[Law enforcement in Russia|Russian police]] and other agencies.
== Crime by type ==
===Murder=== {{Further information|List of countries by intentional homicide rate|List of Russian federal subjects by murder rate}}
In 2016, the murder rate in Russia was 7 per 100,000 <sup>[http://www.gks.ru/free_doc/doc_2017/rusfig/rus17e.pdf <nowiki>[1]</nowiki>]</sup> people, according to Rosstat, also known as the [[Russian Federal State Statistics Service]]. According to UNODC, the corresponding figure is a bit higher at 9.2.[https://dataunodc.un.org/crime/intentional-homicide-victims <sup><nowiki>[2]</nowiki></sup>] Either way, it represents a significant decrease over the previous 15 years (in 2001, the homicide rate was 30.5). In the first quarter of 2018, murder rate in Russia fell by 15% year-over-year; and if the trend continues for the rest of the year, the murder rate will be below that of the United States (5.3 per 100,000 in 2016) for the first time in recent history.<ref>https://www.fedstat.ru/indicator/33559?#</ref><ref>http://www.disastercenter.com/crime/uscrime.htm</ref> In 2017, Moscow also recorded the lowest crime rate in over a decade.<sup>[https://themoscowtimes.com/news/moscow-crime-rate-hits-decade-low-prosecutors-say-60472 <nowiki>[3]</nowiki>]</sup>
At the beginning of the 20th century, Russia had a higher [[homicide]] rate – nearly ten per 100,000 people per year.<ref name="RR121">{{cite book |author= William Alex Pridemore |title= Ruling Russia: Law, Crime, and Justice in a Changing Society |publisher= Rowman & Littlefield |location= |year= 2007 |pages= 121 |isbn= 0-7425-3675-0 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> In the late 1950s and early 1960s, the rate remained stable and it was lower than in the United States.<ref name="RR121"/> There was a rise in the homicide rate in the mid-1960s and 1970s which peaked in 1980, and then slowly declined in until 1985, and then it fell rapidly in 1986–1987.<ref name="RR121"/>
Until the late 1980s, homicide rates in Russia were nearly similar to that in the United States.<ref name="RR121"/> The increase in homicide rate in Russia began slightly earlier than 1990,<ref name="HRRDSR35"/> and rose throughout the 1990s.<ref name="RR121"/> Homicides were more common in Russia than in the [[Baltic states]] in 1991 and nearly doubled in frequency by 1994–1995.<ref name="TBTCTES106">{{cite book |author= Walter C. Clemens |title= The Baltic Transformed: Complexity Theory and European Security |publisher= Rowman & Littlefield |location= |year= 2001 |pages= 106 |isbn= 0-8476-9859-9 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> In 2003, the homicide rate in Russia was among the highest in the world.<ref name=SCIENCEDIRECTMHR>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0277-9536(02)00509-9| title = Measuring homicide in Russia: A comparison of estimates from the crime and vital statistics reporting systems| year = 2003| last1 = Pridemore | first1 = W. A. | journal = Social Science & Medicine| volume = 57| issue = 8| pages = 1343}}</ref> However, by 2017, homicide rate in Russia had fallen by 75%.<sup>[http://www.gks.ru/wps/wcm/connect/rosstat_main/rosstat/ru/statistics/publications/catalog/doc_1135075100641 <nowiki>[4]</nowiki>]</sup> By the end of 2018, Russia's homicide rate may be lower than that of the U.S.
In the early 1980s, an estimated "two-thirds of murders and violent crimes were committed by intoxicated persons".<ref name=Dorman/> In 1995, about three quarters of those arrested for homicide were under the influence of alcohol.<ref name="WHO"/> Things are changing in Russia now, as alcohol consumption has fallen by 80% over the last few years.<sup>[https://themoscowtimes.com/news/russian-alcohol-consumption-falls-80percent-in-5-years-says-minister-60196 <nowiki>[9]</nowiki>]</sup> In 2016, according to [[World Health Organization|WHO]], Russians consumed less alcohol than the people of France, Ireland, Latvia, Lithuania etc. <sup>[http://apps.who.int/gho/data/node.main-euro.A1041?lang=en&showonly=GISAH <nowiki>[10]</nowiki>]</sup>
==== Statistics ====
Below is a comparison of homicide rate in Russia from 1990 to 2017:
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; margin-right:60px" !Year !1990<ref name="http://cbsd.gks.ru/#">{{cite book |author= Jonathan Daniel Weiler |title= Human Rights in Russia: A Darker Side of Reform |publisher= Lynne Rienner Publishers |location= |year= 2004 |pages= 36 |isbn= 1-58826-279-0 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> !1991<ref name="http://cbsd.gks.ru/#" /> !1992<ref name="http://cbsd.gks.ru/#" /> !1993<ref name="http://cbsd.gks.ru/#" /> !1994<ref name="http://cbsd.gks.ru/#" /> !1995<ref name="http://cbsd.gks.ru/#" /> !1996<ref name="http://cbsd.gks.ru/#" /> !1997<ref name="http://cbsd.gks.ru/#" /> !1998<ref name="http://cbsd.gks.ru/#" /> !1999<ref name="http://cbsd.gks.ru/#" /> !2000<ref name="http://cbsd.gks.ru/#" /> !2001<ref name="http://cbsd.gks.ru/#" /> !2002 !2003 !2004 !2005 !2006<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.fedstat.ru/indicator/33559|title=ЕМИСС|website=www.fedstat.ru|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://fedstat.ru/indicator/31270|title=ЕМИСС|website=fedstat.ru|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref> !2007<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> !2008<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> !2009<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> !2010<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> !2011<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> !2012<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> !2013<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> !2014<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> !2015<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> !2016<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> !2017<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> |- |'''Total Homicides'''||21,145||22,621||33,912||45,060||47,870||45,257||39,083||34,995||33,553||38,225||41,090||42,921||44,252||41,764||39,256||35,636||28.513||24.885||23.427||21.121||18.660||16.406 |14.945 |13.912 |12.561 |11.679 |10.331 |8.844 |- ![[List of countries by intentional homicide rate|Homicide rate]] | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |20.02 |17.53 |16.52 |14.9 |13.16 |11.5 |10.4 |9.7 |8.7 |8 |7 |6 |}
According to an official of the [[Russian Ministry of Internal Affairs|Ministry of Internal Affairs]], the homicide rate in Russia in January–November 2006 was 10% less than in the same period of 2005, but 15% of the cases were unsolved.<ref name=RIANOVOSTIRMR>[http://en.rian.ru/russia/20061214/56914119.html Russia's murder rate down 10% but 15% remain unsolved - ministry] ''[[RIA Novosti]]''</ref> Andrei Kucheryavy, the head of a criminal police department, said in a news conference: "The number of killings has been gradually declining in the past four years, while the number of solved murders is increasing."<ref name=RIANOVOSTIRMR/> Approximately 23,500 cases of homicide were registered in the first 10 months of 2006, of which 3,500 were unsolved, 9% less than the previous year.<ref name=RIANOVOSTIRMR/> Between 2006 and 2017, the number of murders in Russia fell by 70% to 8,884. <sup>[https://www.fedstat.ru/indicator/33559?# <nowiki>[13]</nowiki>]</sup>
The age pattern of homicide victimization rates in Russia is different compared to that of the United States.<ref name=ESRDTSPHRR>[http://esr.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/19/1/41 Demographic, Temporal, and Spatial Patterns of Homicide Rates in Russia] ''European Sociological Review''</ref> In 2001, 32% of the homicide victims in Russia were under the age of thirty-five, and 30% of the victims were fifty years or older.<ref name="RR128">{{cite book |author= William Alex Pridemore |title= Ruling Russia: Law, Crime, and Justice in a Changing Society |publisher= Rowman & Littlefield |location= |year= 2007 |pages= 128 |isbn= 0-7425-3675-0 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> There is a wide range of variation in homicide rates throughout Russia. The homicide rate is relatively high in [[Siberia]] and [[Russian Far East]] compared to [[European Russia]].<ref name=ESRDTSPHRR/>
===Drug trafficking=== [[Drug trafficking]] and illicit drug use is a significant problem in Russia.<ref name="PF121">{{cite book |author= Abraham Bob Hoogenboom |title= Policing the Future |publisher= Martinus Nijhoff Publishers |location= |year= 1997 |pages= 121 |isbn= 90-411-0416-X |oclc= |doi= }}</ref><ref name="HRWIDR">{{cite web|title=Rehabilitation Required: Russia’s Human Rights Obligation to Provide Evidence-based Drug Dependence Treatment|work= [[Human Rights Watch]]|url=http://hrw.org/reports/2007/russia1107/russia1107web.pdf}}</ref> The disintegration of the [[Soviet Union]], the [[War in Afghanistan (1978–present)|civil war in Afghanistan]], the [[civil war in Tajikistan]], and the conflicts in the [[North Caucasus]] have made the favorable conditions for the development of illegal drug trade.<ref name="RRF178">{{cite book |author1=Dmitriĭ Trenin |author2=Alekseĭ Vsevolodovich Malashenko |author3=Anatol Lieven |title= Russia's Restless Frontier: The Chechnya Factor in Post-Soviet Russia |publisher= Carnegie Endowment |location= |year= 2004 |pages= 178 |isbn= 0-87003-203-8 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> In the early 1990s, use of [[cocaine]] was increasingly noted among the young population of the nation.<ref name=LOCN>[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?frd/cstdy:@field(DOCID+ru0212) Narcotics] ''Federal Research Division'', ''Library of Congress''</ref>
In the mid-1990s, the growing drug abuse that appeared in Russia was caused by lack of [[border control]]s,<ref name=LOCN/> and the country became one of the world's major transit corridors of drug trafficking.<ref name="EE193">{{cite book |author= Dmitri Trenin |title= The End of Eurasia |publisher= Carnegie Endowment |location= |year= 2002 |pages= 193 |isbn= 0-87003-190-2 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> The entrance of producers of cocaine of [[South America]] in the Russian market was proved by intercepting cocaine shipments in [[Saint Petersburg]] in 1993.<ref name=LOCN/> As of 1996 internal production of narcotic substances was also rising in Russia.<ref name=LOCN/>
Limited quantity of illicit [[Cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] is cultivated in the country.<ref name="CIARUSSIA"/> [[Opium poppies]] and [[marijuana]] are cultivated illegally in the [[Southern Federal District]].<ref name=LOCN/> Russia is one of the two major drug producers along with [[Morocco]], and one of the five major drug trafficking entry points along with [[Iran]], [[Turkey]], [[Italy]] and [[Spain]] in the [[Mediterranean region]].<ref name="SEM436">{{cite book |author= Hans Günter Brauch |title= Security and Environment in the Mediterranean: Conceptualising Security |publisher= Springer |location= |year= 2003 |pages= 436 |isbn= 3-540-40107-5 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> The drug trafficking also involves the supply of [[opium]], heroin and marijuana from [[Central Asia]] and the [[Golden Crescent]], comprising [[Pakistan]], [[Afghanistan]] and [[Iran]].<ref name="EERCA62">{{cite book |author= Imogen Bell |title= Eastern Europe, Russia and Central Asia 2004 |publisher= Routledge |location= |year= |pages= 62–63 |edition= 4th |isbn= 1-85743-187-1 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref>
Russian drug rings work with the [[Sicilian mafia]] and the [[Colombia]]n drug traffickers to import and distribute cocaine.<ref name="TCO261">{{cite book |author= James R. Richards |title= Transnational Criminal Organizations, Cybercrime, and Money Laundering |publisher= CRC Press |location= |year= 1999 |pages= 261 |isbn= 0-8493-2806-3 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> Many local Russian distributors have connections with criminal organizations in [[Central Asia]], the [[Caucasus]], and [[Ukraine]].<ref name=LOCN/> According to the [[Moscow State Institute of International Relations]], a regular trafficking route exists from [[Tajikistan]] to [[Rostov-on-Don]] via [[Turkmenistan]], and from there to [[Western Europe]].<ref name=LOCN/> Below are some drug-trafficking routes through the Russian Federation:
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; margin-right:60px" !Name of Drug !Source country !Destination country |- |'''Poppy straw<ref name="REU93">{{cite book |author1=Oksana Antonenko |author2=Kathryn Pinnick |title= Russia And The European Union: Prospects For A New Relationship |publisher= Routledge |location= |year= 2005 |pages= 93 |isbn= 0-415-35907-4 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref>'''||[[Belarus]], [[Lithuania]], [[Moldova]], [[Ukraine]]||[[Estonia]], [[Poland]] |- |'''Opium<ref name="REU93"/>'''||[[Afghanistan]], [[Azerbaijan]], [[Kyrgyzstan]], [[Pakistan]], [[Tajikistan]], [[Turkmenistan]], [[Uzbekistan]]||[[Canada]], [[Europe]], [[Japan]], [[United States|US]] |- |'''Heroin<ref name="REU93"/>'''||[[Afghanistan]], [[Azerbaijan]], [[Kyrgyzstan]], [[Pakistan]], [[Tajikistan]], [[Turkmenistan]], [[Uzbekistan]]||[[Australia]], [[Canada]], [[Europe]], [[Israel]], [[Japan]], [[United States|US]] |- |'''Cannabis<ref name="REU93"/>'''||[[Afghanistan]], [[Azerbaijan]], [[Kazakhstan]], [[Kyrgyzstan]], [[Turkmenistan]], [[Uzbekistan]]||[[Canada]], [[China]], [[Europe]], [[Japan]], [[Republic of Korea]], [[United States|US]] |- |'''Cocaine<ref name="REU93"/>'''||[[Bolivia]], [[Brazil]], [[Colombia]], [[Europe]], [[Venezuela]], [[United States|US]]||[[Europe]], [[Ghana]], [[Oman]], [[South Africa]], [[Zambia]] |}
Between 1993 and 1995, the annual amount of seized narcotic substances increased from thirty-five tons to ninety tons.<ref name=LOCN/> At present approximately 5 million people use illicit drugs in Russia.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8540726.stm| title= Russia blames Nato for heroin surge from Afghanistan - BBC News February 27, 2010 | date=2010-02-27 | first=Rupert | last=Wingfield-Hayes}}</ref> Russia has the biggest [[heroin]] problem along with Iran and [[Estonia]].<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/background/drugs/users.html The drug trade] ''[[CBC News]]''</ref>
Several measures have been taken by the government to combat drug trafficking. Russia is a party of the 1988 [[United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances]].<ref name=LOCN/> In 1994, when [[Boris Yeltsin]] was the [[President of Russia]], a committee was founded for coordination of drug policy.<ref name=LOCN/> In 1995, a three-year counternarcotics program was approved for establishing drug treatment facilities, criminalization of drug abuse, extension of sentences for drug trafficking, and establishment of pharmaceuticals-monitoring process.<ref name=LOCN/>
In two major anti-drug operations in 1997, fifty metric tons of narcotic substances were seized and approximately 1,400 criminal organizations engaged in drug trafficking were disrupted or destroyed.<ref name="EERCA62"/> In March 2003, Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]] established the Russian State Committee for Control over the Illegal Trafficking of Narcotics and Psychotropic Substances for combating drug trafficking with more coordinated manner.<ref name="REU94">{{cite book |author1=Oksana Antonenko |author2=Kathryn Pinnick |title= Russia And The European Union: Prospects For A New Relationship |publisher= Routledge |location= |year= 2005 |pages= 94 |isbn= 0-415-35907-4 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref>
===Human trafficking=== {{main article|Human trafficking in Russia}} Russia is a supply, transit, and destination country for men, women, and children being [[Human trafficking|trafficked]] for various purposes.<ref name="CIARUSSIA">{{cite web|title=CIA World Factbook - Russia|work= [[CIA World Factbook]]|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/rs.html}}</ref><ref name="RR167">{{cite book |author= William Alex Pridemore |title= Ruling Russia: Law, Crime, and Justice in a Changing Society |publisher= Rowman & Littlefield |location= |year= 2007 |pages= 167 |isbn= 0-7425-3675-0 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> The trafficking is multidimensional and it involves both commercial sexual exploitation and labor exploitation.<ref name="RR167"/> Russia is a significant source of women trafficked to over 50 nations.<ref name="CIARUSSIA"/> Internal trafficking is a problem in the country; women are trafficked from rural areas to urban settlements for commercial sexual exploitation.<ref name="CIARUSSIA"/> Men are trafficked internally and from [[Central Asia]] for forced labor in the [[construction]] and agricultural industries.<ref name="CIARUSSIA"/> [[Debt bondage]] is common among the trafficking victims.<ref name="CIARUSSIA"/>
===Arms trafficking=== [[Arms trafficking]] has become a significant problem in the Russian Federation following the disintegration of the Soviet Union.<ref name="EERCA62"/> The former [[Eastern Bloc]] countries (including Russia) are the source of the majority of illegal weapons in circulation around the world.<ref name=CDIISWFWAW>[http://www.cdi.org/russia/162.html##10 Illegal Soviet Weapons Fuel Wars Around World] ''[[Center for Defense Information]]''</ref> Illegal arms possession is a problem in many regions in the nation, especially in the areas suffering from insurgency such as [[Chechnya]] and [[Dagestan]].<ref name=SMALLARMSSURVEY>[http://www.smallarmssurvey.org/files/sas/publications/o_papers_pdf/2003-op10-russia.pdf Beyond the Kalashnikov: Small Arms Production, Exports, and Stockpiles in the Russian Federation] ''Small Arms Survey''</ref>
Because of the general weakening of the government control and the decentralization of power in the nation in the first half of the 1990s, small arms from several military units and arsenals made their way into the hands of civilians and local unofficial armed formations.<ref name=SMALLARMSSURVEY/> Gunrunning in Russia stemmed from corruption in the [[Armed Forces of the Russian Federation|armed forces]] and the illegal sale of military equipment.<ref name="EERCA62"/> It has been suggested that parts of the [[Russian Ministry of Defence|Ministry of Defence of the Russian Federation]] and [[arms industry]] were engaged in arms trafficking with the Chechen separatists.<ref name="MCWPC191">{{cite book |author1=Bruno Coppieters |author2=Nick Fotion |title= Moral Constraints on War: Principles and Cases |publisher= Lexington Books |location= |year= 2002 |pages= 191 |isbn= 0-7391-0437-3 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref>
Russian troops play an important role in arms trafficking especially in the war zones.<ref name="BSRCSB230">{{cite book |author1=Oleksandr Pavliuk |author2=Ivanna Klympush |title= The Black Sea Region: Cooperation and Security Building |publisher= M.E. Sharpe |location= |year= 2003 |pages= 230 |isbn= 0-7656-1225-9 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> Poor salary for service persons coupled with lack of control over weapon storage resulted in troop involvement in illegal arms trade.<ref name="BSRCSB230"/> The [[Chief of the General Staff (Russia)|Chief of the General Staff]] [[Anatoly Kvashnin]] publicly stated in 2003 that increasing corruption left the Russian military in a "post-critical state".<ref name="BSRCSB230"/>
There have been accusations and counter-accusations between Russia and [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] regarding illegal arms selling to Chechen separatists. Russia alleged that Chechen separatists received weapons through illegal networks going to Chechnya through Georgia and [[Azerbaijan]].<ref name="BSRCSB231">{{cite book |author1=Oleksandr Pavliuk |author2=Ivanna Klympush |title= The Black Sea Region: Cooperation and Security Building |publisher= M.E. Sharpe |location= |year= 2003 |pages= 231 |isbn= 0-7656-1225-9 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> On the other hand, Georgia accused Russia of corruption on military bases, poor security infrastructure and low professionalism among Russian troops as the reasons behind the spread of illegal weapons.<ref name="BSRCSB231"/>
The types of firearms in illegal possession varies throughout the nation: in [[Siberia]] unregistered [[Hunting weapon#Rifles|hunting rifles]] are the primarily found illegal weapons while in Chechnya the predominant illicit arms are illegally held military weapons.<ref name=SMALLARMSSURVEY/> Small arms are illegally proliferated from the main centers of small arms manufacturing, [[Tula Oblast|Tula]] and [[Izhevsk]].<ref name=SMALLARMSSURVEY/> In 2003 an estimated 300,000 to 1.5 million illegal arms were in circulation within Russia.<ref name=SMALLARMSSURVEY/>
According to the statistics from the [[Supreme Court of the Russian Federation]], 1.5 times more people were arrested for gunrunning in 2001 than in 2000; in total 26,113 arrests were made and 65,000 crimes were committed using illegal arms.<ref name="EERCA62"/> In 2000, the number of seized unregistered firearms was 300,000, which was a 37% increase compared with 1999.<ref name="EERCA62"/> Many Russian criminal organizations, aside from arms trafficking in Russia, provide weapons to the separatists groups in [[Chechnya]].<ref name="PC165"/>
However several attempts were made to combat arms trafficking. Small arms manufacturers in the country have tightened their security systems.<ref name=SMALLARMSSURVEY/> Special prosecutors’ offices, which were originally set up in the 1950s for supervising secrecy in nuclear facilities, have been given the responsibility of the security of defense plants and curbing the theft of small arms from the plants.<ref name=SMALLARMSSURVEY/> The [[Government of Russia]] has undertaken a programme to increase security at arms storage facilities at military bases.<ref name=SMALLARMSSURVEY/>
===Poaching=== [[Poaching]] was extremely uncommon in the [[Soviet Union]],<ref name="LASUNIRTCA40">{{cite book |author= Nozar Alaolmolki |title= Life After the Soviet Union: The Newly Independent Republics of the Transcaucasus and Central Asia |publisher= SUNY Press |location= |year= 2001 |pages= 40 |isbn= 0-7914-5137-2 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> but has recently become a significant problem in the country. The main cause for poaching in Russia is the consequence of the social and political changes since the dissolution of the Soviet Union.<ref name=EAZAIFDNWSL>[http://www.eaza.net/magazine/download/Cons53_helsinki_snowleopard.pdf IN FOCUS: DECLINING NUMBERS OF WILD SNOW LEOPARDS] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080408194148/http://www.eaza.net/magazine/download/Cons53_helsinki_snowleopard.pdf |date=2008-04-08 }} ''[[European Association of Zoos and Aquaria]]''</ref> State-controlled farms stopped functioning due to the fall of the previous system resulting in high [[unemployment]].<ref name=EAZAIFDNWSL/> Unemployment, [[poverty]], [[inflation]], shortage of food and demand for foreign currency have major impact on the wildlife in the country.<ref name=EAZAIFDNWSL/>
Between 1992 and 1996, law enforcement agencies in Russia mainly focused on [[drug trafficking]], [[arms trafficking]], [[money laundering]] and the [[First Chechen War]]. [[Environmental crime]]s like [[poaching]] and illegal timber smuggling were generally not treated as national security issues.<ref name="SWT358">{{cite book |author= Valmik Thapar |title= Saving Wild Tigers 1900-2000: The Essential Writings |publisher= Orient Longman |location= |year= 2006 |pages= 358 |isbn= 81-7824-150-1 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> During the post-[[perestroika]] transition, the government agencies for environment and wildlife protection experienced severe budget cuts<ref name="SWT358"/> which led to layoffs and salary reductions for wildlife rangers in places like [[Primorski Krai]] and it reduced the resources of the rangers to fight against the poachers.<ref name="SWT359">{{cite book |author= Valmik Thapar |title= Saving Wild Tigers 1900-2000: The Essential Writings |publisher= Orient Longman |location= |year= 2006 |pages= 359 |isbn= 81-7824-150-1 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> Animals being poached in the country are [[bear]], [[musk deer]], [[tiger]] etc.<ref name="SWT359"/> Approximately 50,000 cases of poaching are registered annually.<ref name="PGNU540">{{cite book |author= Maria Shahgedanova |title= The Physical Geography of Northern Eurasia |publisher= Oxford University Press |location= |year= 2002 |pages= 540 |isbn= 0-19-823384-1 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref>{{Update after|2010|11}} According to the tiger experts and enforcement officers in Russia, the characteristics of tiger poaching in Russia are: *Tiger poaching is carried out by two sets of poachers: organized poaching gangs and opportunistic poachers.<ref name="SWT360">{{cite book |author= Valmik Thapar |title= Saving Wild Tigers 1900-2000: The Essential Writings |publisher= Orient Longman |location= |year= 2006 |pages= 360 |isbn= 81-7824-150-1 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref>
*Poaching of the tiger's prey base (i.e. wild pig and deer) occur for the consumption of the local population.<ref name="SWT360"/> *The poachers generally sell the tiger parts to middlemen operating out of the cities like [[Vladivostok]], [[Khabarovsk]], [[Ussuriysk]], [[Nakhodka]] and [[Plastun (urban-type settlement)|Plastun]].<ref name="SWT360"/> *The middlemen who buy or sell tiger parts are generally [[Russians]], [[Koryo-saram|ethnic Koreans]], or [[Chinese people in Russia|Chinese]].<ref name="SWT360"/> *Most tiger parts are being smuggled to the [[People's Republic of China]], [[South Korea]] and [[Japan]].<ref name="SWT360"/>
It is believed that sharp increase in poaching in the first half of the 1990s resulted in rapid decrease of the [[Siberian tiger]] population.<ref name="PWCC305">{{cite book |author1=Rosie Woodroffe |author2=Simon Thirgood |author3=Alan Rabinowitz |title= People and Wildlife: Conflict Or Coexistence? |publisher= Cambridge University Press |location= |year= 2005 |pages= 305 |isbn= 0-521-82505-9 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> According to estimation, there were 330 to 371 adult Siberian tigers in the [[Russian Far East]] in 1996 while the number was 600 at the end of the 1980s.<ref name="PWCC305"/> During the communist rule, borders were closed and access to the Asian demand for tiger products was almost non-existent.<ref name="PWCC310">{{cite book |author1=Rosie Woodroffe |author2=Simon Thirgood |author3=Alan Rabinowitz |title= People and Wildlife: Conflict Or Coexistence? |publisher= Cambridge University Press |location= |year= 2005 |pages= 310 |isbn= 0-521-82505-9 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> Due to this, from 1972 to 1992, poaching was not reported.<ref name="PWCC310"/>
The collapse of the Soviet Union resulted in easing of border controls and gun laws, and it became an urgent need for the villagers to earn income in a destroyed economy with high inflation.<ref name="PWCC310"/> Almost immediately tigers became similar to a profitable cash crop at a time when there was huge demand for tiger parts for [[Traditional Chinese medicine]].<ref name="PWCC310"/> Data obtained from field examinations, skin confiscations and from radio-collared animals indicated that 58%-73% tiger deaths were related to poaching.<ref name="PWCC310"/> Poaching of tigers apparently peaked in the early 1990s.<ref name="PWCC314">{{cite book |author1=Rosie Woodroffe |author2=Simon Thirgood |author3=Alan Rabinowitz |title= People and Wildlife: Conflict Or Coexistence? |publisher= Cambridge University Press |location= |year= 2005 |pages= 314 |isbn= 0-521-82505-9 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref>
The collapse of the Marxist-Leninist government in the country had a significant influence on the average Russian's economic ability to maintain his or her family. Because of the large population of bears in Russia and an increasing demand for bear parts, especially bile,<ref name="HBBBGPB177">{{cite book |author= Kathy Etling |title= Hunting Bears: Black, Brown, Grizzly, And Polar Bears |publisher= Woods N' Water, Inc. |location= |year= 2003 |pages= 177 |isbn= 0-9722804-1-3 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> poaching of bears became increasingly popular. Its main trade partners in bear parts are primarily nearby Asian countries like [[South Korea]] and the [[People's Republic of China]].<ref name="HBBBGPB177"/> Poaching of the [[snow leopard]] is also a serious problem in [[Russia]] along with [[Afghanistan]], [[India]], [[Kazakhstan]], [[Kyrgyzstan]], [[Mongolia]], [[Nepal]], [[Pakistan]], [[People’s Republic of China]], [[Tajikistan]] and [[Uzbekistan]].<ref name=EAZAIFDNWSL/> The situation for [[antelopes]] has deteriorated significantly since the collapse of the Soviet system.<ref name="GSRAPA217">{{cite book |author1=D. P. Mallon |author2=S. C. Kingswood |title= Antelopes: global survey and regional action plans. Part 4: North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia |publisher= IUCN |location= |year= 2001 |pages= 217 |isbn= 2-8317-0594-0 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> There has been increase in poaching of the [[saiga antelope]] which reduced the saiga population in the country.<ref name="GSRAPA217"/>
However several attempts were made to combat commercial poaching of animals. [[Operation Amba]], started to curtail the poaching of [[Siberian tiger]]s in the [[Russian Far East]],<ref name="RTTCHDL235">{{cite book |author1=John Seidensticker |author2=Peter Jackson |author3=Sarah Christie |title= Riding the Tiger: Tiger Conservation in Human-dominated Landscapes |publisher= Cambridge University Press |location= |year= 1999 |pages= 235 |isbn= 0-521-64835-1 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref><ref name=TURNERFOUNDATION>[http://www.turnerfoundation.org/grants/HGDetail7.asp Highlighted grants] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612205950/http://www.turnerfoundation.org/grants/HGDetail7.asp |date=2008-06-12 }} ''Turner Foundation, Inc.''</ref> is credited for bringing the Amur tiger back from the brink of extinction in the mid-1990s.<ref name=WILDLIFEALLIANCE>[http://www.wildlifealliance.org/where-we-work/thailand/team/steve-galster.html Steve Galster] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612235402/http://www.wildlifealliance.org/where-we-work/thailand/team/steve-galster.html |date=2008-06-12 }} ''Wildlife Alliance''</ref><ref>[http://www.orangutan.com/about_people.html The People] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071015070948/http://orangutan.com/about_people.html |date=2007-10-15 }} ''Orangutan.com''</ref><ref name="RTTCHDL240">{{cite book |author1=John Seidensticker |author2=Peter Jackson |author3=Sarah Christie |title= Riding the Tiger: Tiger Conservation in Human-dominated Landscapes |publisher= Cambridge University Press |location= |year= 1999 |pages= 240 |isbn= 0-521-64835-1 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref>
Major General Vitaly Ivanovich Gamov,<ref name=comeback>[http://www.nomad.su/?a=15-200205310008 "Я вернусь домой генералом..." ] [[Karavan]] 31 May 2002</ref> a Deputy Commander of the Pacific Regional Directorate of the [[Border Guard Service of Russia]],<ref>[http://www.regnum.ru/news/564622.html Расследование уголовного дела об убийстве генерала Гамова завершено] [[REGNUM News Agency|Regnum]]</ref> was killed in 2002 in his house after refusing to take bribes and allow poachers to outsource their recourse to Japan.<ref name=gazeta>[http://www.gazeta.ru/social/2008/06/19/2758924.shtml Гамова сожгли неосторожные хулиганы] [[Gazeta.ru]] 19 June 2008</ref>
In January 2009, the [[Altaigate Scandal]] developed after the Plenipotentiary of the Russian President in the State Duma was killed along with 6 other officials in the helicopter crash accident (poaching for legally protected [[argali]] mountain sheep) and an entire investigation was concealed from the public.
===Corruption=== {{Further information|Corruption in Russia}}
In Russia's criminal legislation, "[[Political corruption|corruption]]" is not defined as a specific crime, but a collective term which include bribery, abuse of office and others.<ref name="DRPPRFRR320">{{cite book |author1=Peter Reddaway |author2=Robert W. Orttung |title= Dynamics of Russian Politics: Putin's Reform of Federal-Regional Relations (Vol. II) |publisher= Rowman & Littlefield |location= |year= 2005 |pages= 320 |isbn= 0-7425-2646-1 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> It is accepted in both inside and outside the country that corruption is widespread in Russia.<ref name=IMF>[http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/seminar/2000/invest/pdf/roaf.pdf Corruption in Russia] ''[[International Monetary Fund]]''</ref> Corruption is often considered as a major factor behind economic problems in the nation.<ref name=IMF/> According to a survey conducted by the [[Economist Intelligence Unit]] in 1997, the [[Commonwealth of Independent States]] was the most corrupt region in the world, with Russia (along with the other four CIS countries surveyed) received the maximum rating for corruption among public officials.<ref name=IMF/>
In the [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] 2007, Russia was ranked 143rd out of 179 countries for corruption (least corrupt countries are at the top of the list).<ref name=TICPI2007>[http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2007 Corruption Perceptions Index 2007] ''[[Transparency International]]''</ref> On a scale of 0 to 10 with 0 the most corrupt and 10 the most transparent, [[Transparency International]] rated Russia 2.3.<ref name=TICPI2007/> Corruption in Russia is often divided into two broad categories: "petty" corruption, where low-ranking government officials are engaged in bribery, and "high-level" corruption involving political and business elite.<ref name=IMF/> Below are selected official data on corruption in Russia from 1997 to 2003:
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; margin-right:60px" !Year !1997<ref name="DRPPRFRR321">{{cite book |author1=Peter Reddaway |author2=Robert W. Orttung |title= Dynamics of Russian Politics: Putin's Reform of Federal-Regional Relations (Vol. II) |publisher= Rowman & Littlefield |location= |year= 2005 |pages= 321 |isbn= 0-7425-2646-1 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> !1998<ref name="DRPPRFRR321"/> !1999<ref name="DRPPRFRR321"/> !2000<ref name="DRPPRFRR321"/> !2001<ref name="DRPPRFRR321"/> !2002<ref name="DRPPRFRR321"/> !2003<ref name="DRPPRFRR321"/> |- |'''Embezzlement (''prisvoenie'' or ''rastrata'')'''||-||-||-||-||46,848||43,859||44,706 |- |'''Bribery (''vzyatochnichestvo'')'''||5,068||5,805||6,823||7,047||7,909||7,311||7,346 |}
Corruption in the police force is a significant problem in the country.<ref name="DRPPRFRR322">{{cite book |author1=Peter Reddaway |author2=Robert W. Orttung |title= Dynamics of Russian Politics: Putin's Reform of Federal-Regional Relations (Vol. II) |publisher= Rowman & Littlefield |location= |year= 2005 |pages= 322 |isbn= 0-7425-2646-1 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> First Deputy Minister of Internal Affairs Vladimir Vasilev claimed that 1,700 police persons were convicted of bribery or abuse of office in 2001 and the problem of corruption was under control.<ref name="DRPPRFRR322"/> But according to most observers, in reality the level of police corruption is much higher and state officials like to downplay the problem of corruption.<ref name="DRPPRFRR322"/>
Political analyst [[Andrei Piontkovsky]] said in an article written in early 2000 that the then current political system in Russia was "the highest stage of robber [[capitalism]]”.<ref>[http://www.cdi.org/russia/johnson/4094.html#1 Putinism: highest stage of robber capitalism] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070711235241/http://www.cdi.org/russia/johnson/4094.html#1#1 |date=2007-07-11 }}, by [[Andrei Piontkovsky]], The Russia Journal, February 7–13, 2000. The title is an allusion to work ''"[[Imperialism]] as the last and culminating stage of capitalism"'' by [[Vladimir Lenin]]</ref> He believes that "Russia is not corrupt. [[Political corruption|Corruption]] is what happens in all countries when businessmen offer officials large bribes for favors. Today’s Russia is unique. The businessmen, the politicians, and the bureaucrats are the same people. They have [[privatization|privatized]] the country’s wealth and taken control of its financial flows." <ref>[http://www.hudson.org/index.cfm?fuseaction=publication_details&id=4852 Review of Andrei's Pionkovsky's ''Another Look Into Putin's Soul'' by the Honorable Rodric Braithwaite] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927230557/http://www.hudson.org/index.cfm?fuseaction=publication_details&id=4852 |date=2007-09-27 }}, [[Hoover Institute]]</ref>
Such views are also shared by former [[CIA]] director [[James Woolsey]] who said in a 1999 Congressional Statement: "I have been particularly concerned for some years, beginning during my tenure, with the interpenetration of Russian [[organized crime]], Russian intelligence and law enforcement, and Russian business. I have often illustrated this point with the following hypothetical: If you should chance to strike up a conversation with an articulate, English-speaking Russian in, say, the restaurant of one of the luxury hotels along Lake Geneva, and he is wearing a $3,000 suit and a pair of Gucci loafers, and he tells you that he is an executive of a Russian trading company and wants to talk to you about a joint venture, then there are four possibilities. He may be what he says he is. He may be a Russian intelligence officer working under commercial cover. He may be part of a Russian organized crime group. But the really interesting possibility is that he may be all three and that none of those three institutions have any problem with the arrangement." <ref>(''Congressional Statement of R. James Woolsey, Former Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, 21 September 1999, Hearing on the Bank of New York and Russian Money Laundering'')</ref><ref name="Takeover">[https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/08850600500483699 The Chekist Takeover of the Russian State], Anderson, Julie (2006), International Journal of Intelligence and Counter-Intelligence, 19:2, 237 - 288.</ref>
According to Transparency International, bribery in Russia is worth $300 billion.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/8632240.stm| title= Foreign firms pledge not to give bribes in Russia -BBC News | first=Konstantin | last=Rozhnov | date=2010-04-21}}</ref>
==Historical trends== {{See also|Crime in the Soviet Union}} [[File:Crime and incarceration rates in Russia.svg|thumb]]
Comparison of the crime rates of the [[Soviet Union]] with those of other nations is considered difficult, because the Soviet Union did not publish comprehensive crime statistics.<ref name=LOCCS>[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?frd/cstdy:@field(DOCID+ru0209) Crime in the Soviet Era] ''Federal Research Division'', ''[[Library of Congress]]''</ref> According to Western experts, robberies, homicide and other violent crimes were less prevalent in the Soviet Union than in the [[United States]] because the Soviet Union had a larger police force, strict gun controls, and had a low occurrence of [[drug abuse]].<ref name=LOCCS/> However, [[white-collar crime]] was prevalent in the Soviet system. Corruption in the form of bribery was common, primarily due to the paucity of goods and services on the open market.<ref name=LOCCS/>
Theft of state property (embezzlement) by state employees was also common.<ref name=LOCCS/> When [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] was the [[General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|General Secretary of the CPSU]], an effort was made to stop white-collar crime.<ref name=LOCCS/> Revelations of corruption scandals involving high-level employees of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] were published regularly in the [[news media]] of the Soviet Union, and many arrests and prosecutions resulted from such discoveries.<ref name=LOCCS/> An article published in the ''[[Izvestia]]'' in 1994 described the difference between the situation of crime in the Soviet Union and post-Soviet Russia:<ref name="CRS135136">{{cite book |author= Thane Gustafson |title= Capitalism Russian-style |publisher= Cambridge University Press |location= |year= 1999 |pages= 135–136 |isbn= 0-521-64175-6 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> {{quotation|Crime was never able to gain enough strength to compete with the state's law enforcement system. The criminal world had ties with the police, but it was all kept deeply hidden. Money had influence, but it was not all-powerful. Laundering the profits from crime was difficult, and spending the profits equally so. There were millionaires, but they were underground. There were gangs - but to get weapons they had to run numerous risks. We had it all. But it was all under the surface.<ref name="CRS135136"/>}}
The crime rate in Russia sharply increased during the late 1980s.<ref name="HRRDSR35">{{cite book |author= Jonathan Daniel Weiler |title= Human Rights in Russia: A Darker Side of Reform |publisher= Lynne Rienner Publishers |location= |year= 2004 |pages= 35 |isbn= 1-58826-279-0 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> The fall of [[Marxist-Leninist]] governments in [[Eastern Europe]] had tremendous influence on the political economy of organized crime.<ref name="PC165">{{cite book |author= Robert Harris |title= Political Corruption: In and Beyond the Nation State |publisher= Routledge |location= |year= 2003 |pages= 165 |isbn= 0-415-23555-3 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref>
=== Post Soviet ===
The collapse of the Soviet Union destroyed much of the systems and infrastructures that provided [[social security]] and a minimal [[standard of living]] for the population,<ref name=URITFSE>[http://www.uri.edu/artsci/wms/hughes/russia.pdf Trafficking for Sexual Exploitation: The Case of the Russian Federation] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080408194147/http://www.uri.edu/artsci/wms/hughes/russia.pdf |date=2008-04-08 }} ''[[University of Rhode Island]]''</ref> and law and order across the country broke down resulting in outbreak of crime.<ref name="RTTCHDL232">{{cite book |author1=John Seidensticker |author2=Peter Jackson |author3=Sarah Christie |title= Riding the Tiger: Tiger Conservation in Human-dominated Landscapes |publisher= Cambridge University Press |location= |year= 1999 |pages= 232 |isbn= 0-521-64835-1 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref> In the transition to a [[market economy|free market economy]], production fell and there was huge [[capital flight]] coupled with low [[foreign direct investment|foreign investment]].<ref name=URITFSE/>
Due to these factors, economic instability increased and a newly impoverished population emerged, accompanied by [[unemployment]] and unpaid wages.<ref name=URITFSE/> [[Extreme poverty]] as well as unpaid wages resulted in an increase in theft and counterfeiting.<ref name="FASRUSSIA"> {{cite web|title=THE RISE OF ORGANIZED CRIME |url=https://fas.org/news/russia/2000/russia/part07.htm}} ''[[Federation of American Scientists]]'' </ref> Since the dissolution of the Soviet Union, organized criminal groups in Russia and other former Soviet republics have been involved in different illegal activities such as drug trafficking, arms trafficking, car theft, human trafficking and money laundering being the most common.<ref name="CTC312">{{cite book |author= Larry J. Siegel |title= Criminology: The Core |publisher= Thomson Wadsworth |location= |year= 2004 |pages= 312 |isbn= 0-534-62937-7 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref>
The internationalization of the [[Russian Mafia]] along with the [[Sicilian Mafia]], the [[Camorra]], the [[Triad society|Triads]] and the [[Yakuza]] played a vital role in the development of transnational crime<ref name="PC165"/> involving Russia. From 1991 to 1992, the number of both officially reported crimes and the overall crime rate increased by 27%.<ref name=LOCCS/> By the early 1990s, theft, burglary, and other property crimes accounted for nearly two-thirds of all crime in the country.<ref name=LOCCS/> There was a rapid growth of violent crime, including homicides.<ref name=LOCCS/> However, since the beginning of the 2000s, crime in Russia has taken a sharp decline.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://www.gks.ru/free_doc/2008/demo/osn/05-07.htm|title=Коэффициенты смертности по основным классам причин смерти|publisher=|accessdate=21 June 2015}}</ref>
==Crime dynamics==
=== 1990s === Russia's economy experienced a 40% GDP decline in the 1990s, <sup>[https://www.thenation.com/article/harvard-boys-do-russia/ <nowiki>[3]</nowiki>]</sup> and this led to an explosion of crime. In 1990, the number of registered crime was 1.84 million.<ref name="HRRDSR35" /> This figure increased to 2.8 million in 1993, then fell slightly.<ref name="HRRDSR35" /> In 1996, there were a total of 2.63 million officially registered crimes, which was more than 40% higher than in 1990.<ref name="HRRDSR35" /> In 1999, total reported crime was 3 million, and it continued to increase in 2000 and 2001, and then fell in 2002.<ref name="HRRDSR35" />
Among white-collar crimes, swindling increased 67.2 percent, and extortion 37.5 percent, in 1995.<ref name="LOCCS" /> Among the conventional crimes reported in 1995, homicide and attempted murder increased 1.5%, rape 6.5%, burglaries 6.6%.<ref name="LOCCS" /> Serious crimes by teenagers increased by 2.2 percent in 1995.<ref name="LOCCS" />
In the first four months in 1994, Russia averaged eighty-four murders per day.<ref name=LOCCS/> Many of those crimes were contract killings by criminal organizations.<ref name=LOCCS/> The 1995 national crime total exceeded 1.3 million, including 30,600 cases of homicide.<ref name=LOCCS/>
=== Recent Years === The Putin years (2001-now) have seen substantial decrease in crime -- for example, the number of murders and suicides in Russia is stated to have been dropped by 80%.<ref>http://www.gks.ru/free_doc/doc_2017/rusfig/rus17e.pdf</ref>
=== By region ===
{{Further information|List of Russian federal subjects by murder rate}}
2017 was a very good year for Moscow, which saw the lowest number of crimes (140,000) in a decade. <sup>[http://tass.ru/moskva/4943699 <nowiki>[1]</nowiki>]</sup> Theft, burglary and armed robbery dropped up to 38 percent since the previous year, while the murder rate dropped by 10 percent. Crime statistics of Moscow for 1995 included a total of 93,560 cases of crime, of which 18,500 were [[white-collar crime]]s, an increase of 8.3% over 1994.<ref name="LOCCS 0210">{{cite web|url=http://lcweb2.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?frd/cstdy:@field(DOCID+ru0210)|title=Crime Statistics|publisher=|accessdate=21 June 2015}}</ref>
The majority of car thefts were reported from [[Moscow]] and [[Saint Petersburg]], which increased through the first half of the 1990s.<ref name=LOCCS/> In Moscow an estimated fifty cars were stolen per day, with the estimated yearly total for Russia between 100,000 and 150,000.<ref name=LOCCS/>
=== Alcohol and crime ===
{{See also|Alcoholism in Russia}}
In the early 1980s, an estimated "two-thirds of murders and violent crimes were committed by intoxicated persons; and drunk drivers were responsible for 14,000 traffic deaths and 60,000 serious traffic injuries".<ref name=Dorman>{{cite journal |last1=Dorman |first1=Nancy D. |last2=Towle |first2=Leland H. |year=1991 |title=Initiatives to curb alcohol abuse and alcoholism in the former Soviet Union |journal=Alcohol Health & Research World |publisher= |volume= |issue= |pages= |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0847/is_n4_v15/ai_12754655/?tag=content;col1}}</ref> In 1995, about three quarters of those arrested for homicide were under the influence of alcohol.<ref name="WHO">{{cite web |url=http://www.euro.who.int/document/e88757.pdf |title=Interpersonal Violence and Alcohol in the Russian Federation |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |year=2006 |accessdate=May 12, 2010}}</ref>
A 1997 report published in the ''Journal of Family Violence'', found that among male perpetrators of spousal homicide, 60–75% of offenders had been drinking prior to the incident.<ref name="WHO p4">{{cite web |url=http://www.euro.who.int/document/e88757.pdf |title=Interpersonal Violence and Alcohol in the Russian Federation |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |year=2006 |accessdate=May 12, 2010| page =4}}</ref> In a 2004 study of domestic violence in the [[Central Black Earth Region]] of Russia, 77% of offenders of violent crime towards family members were frequent drinkers - 12% engaged in regular binge drinking three or four times a month, 30% three times a week or more, and 35% every day or almost every day.<ref name="WHO p4"/>
===International comparison=== Homicide/murder rate in Russia has fallen dramatically in the last two decades. The homicide rate in Russia more than tripled between 1988 and 1994 and was among the [[List of countries by murder rate|highest in the world]].<ref name=SCIENCEDIRECTMHR /> However, by 2017, the murder rate in Russia was only slightly higher than in the US (6 versus 5.6) <sup>[https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/murder-is-up-again-in-2017-but-not-as-much-as-last-year/ <nowiki>[7]</nowiki>][https://www.fedstat.ru/indicator/33559?# <nowiki>[8]</nowiki>]</sup>. Compared to Russia, murder rates in large American cities are vastly higher -- for example, it's 17 in Miami and 55 in Baltimore.<sup>[https://bismarcktribune.com/news/national/the-cities-with-the-highest-murder-rates-in-the-us/collection_5a789407-4d43-5403-ad56-7c47880bda8e.html#5 <nowiki>[8]</nowiki>]</sup> In 1998, a total of 24,537,600 crimes were recorded in United States, while in Russia a total of 2,581,940 crimes were recorded.<ref name=SEVENTHUNSURVEY>[http://www.nplc.lt/stat/int/7sc.pdf Seventh United Nations Survey of Crime Trends and Operations of Criminal Justice Systems] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080308202851/http://www.nplc.lt/stat/int/7sc.pdf |date=2008-03-08 }}</ref> In 1999, the number was 23,677,800 and 3,001,748 respectively.<ref name=SEVENTHUNSURVEY/> Total recorded rapes in the United States was 93,140 and 89,110 for the years 1998 and 1999, while this number was 7,724 and 7,314 respectively for Russia.<ref name=SEVENTHUNSURVEY/> Using the revised definition, [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] recorded 114,730 rapes in the US in 2016. <sup>[https://ucr.fbi.gov/crime-in-the-u.s/2016/crime-in-the-u.s.-2016/tables/table-11 <nowiki>[10]</nowiki>]</sup> {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; margin-right:60px" !Country !Russia <sup>[https://www.fedstat.ru/indicator/33559?# <nowiki>[73]</nowiki>]</sup> !Russia <sup>[https://www.fedstat.ru/indicator/33559?# <nowiki>[74]</nowiki>]</sup> !Japan<ref name="National homicide rates, UN data published by Nation Master.com"/> !Germany<ref name="BKA, German federal crime statistics (German)">{{cite web|url=http://www.bka.de/pks/pks2004ev/pcs_2004.pdf|title=BKA, German federal crime statistics|accessdate=2006-09-27|archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20070621063513/http://www.bka.de/pks/pks2004ev/pcs_2004.pdf|archive-date=2007-06-21|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> !United Kingdom<ref name="National homicide rates, UN data published by Nation Master.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.nationmaster.com/graph/cri_mur_percap-crime-murders-per-capita#rest|title=National homicide rates, UN data published by Nation Master.com|accessdate=2006-09-29}}</ref> !France<ref name="National homicide rates, UN data published by Nation Master.com"/> !Canada<ref name="Crime in Canada, Canada Statistics">{{cite web|url=http://www.statcan.ca/Daily/English/050721/d050721a.htm|title=Crime in Canada, Canada Statistics|accessdate=2006-09-27 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060828065139/http://www.statcan.ca/Daily/English/050721/d050721a.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2006-08-28}}</ref> !Poland<ref name="National homicide rates, UN data published by Nation Master.com"/> !United States <sup>[https://ucr.fbi.gov/crime-in-the-u.s/2016/crime-in-the-u.s.-2016/tables/table-11 <nowiki>[77]</nowiki>]</sup> !South Africa<ref name="National homicide rates, UN data published by Nation Master.com"/> !Colombia<ref name="National homicide rates, UN data published by Nation Master.com"/> |- |'''Homicide rate'''||30.5||6||0.500||1.4||1.406||1.733||1.9||5.628||5.4||49.600||61.785 |- |'''Year'''||2001||2017||''2000''||''2000''||''2000''||''2000''||''2004''||''2000''||2016||''2000''||''2000'' |}

{{Medical anthropology}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} In [[medicine]] and [[medical anthropology]], a '''culture-bound syndrome''', '''culture-specific syndrome''', or '''folk illness''' is a combination of psychiatric and somatic [[symptom]]s that are considered to be a recognizable disease only within a specific society or [[culture]]. There are no objective biochemical or structural alterations of [[organ (anatomy)|body organs]] or functions, and the disease is not recognized in other cultures. The term ''culture-bound syndrome'' was included in the fourth version of the ''[[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]]'' ([[American Psychiatric Association]], 1994) which also includes a list of the most common culture-bound conditions ([[DSM-IV]]: Appendix I). Counterpart within the framework of [[ICD-10]] ([[ICD-10 Chapter V: Mental and behavioural disorders|Chapter V]]) are the ''culture-specific disorders'' defined in Annex 2 of the ''Diagnostic criteria for research''.[http://www.who.int/entity/classifications/icd/en/GRNBOOK.pdf Diagnostic criteria for research], p. 213–225 ([[World Health Organization|WHO]] 1993) More broadly, an [[epidemic]] that can be attributed to cultural behavior patterns or [[suggestion]] is sometimes referred to as a '''behavioral epidemic'''. As in the cases of [[drug abuse|drug]] or [[alcohol abuse|alcohol]] abuse or smoking, [[Transmission (medicine)|transmission]] can be determined by [[communal reinforcement]] as well as by person-to-person interactions. On [[etiological]] grounds, it can be difficult to distinguish the causal contribution of culture in disease from other [[environmental factor]]s such as [[toxicity]].{{cite encyclopedia|editor=Porta, Miquel |encyclopedia=A Dictionary of Epidemiology| edition=5th | title=Behavioral epidemic | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s7R-MLMyEgwC&pg=PT48|accessdate=25 August 2013| year=2008| publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-157844-1|page=48}} ==Identification== A culture-specific syndrome is characterized by:{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}} # categorization as a [[disease]] in the culture (i.e., not a voluntary behaviour or false claim); # widespread familiarity in the culture; # complete lack of familiarity or misunderstanding of the condition to people in other cultures; # no objectively demonstrable biochemical or tissue abnormalities (signs); # the condition is usually recognized and treated by the [[folk medicine]] of the culture. Some culture-specific syndromes involve somatic symptoms (pain or disturbed function of a body part), while others are purely behavioral. Some culture-bound syndromes appear with similar features in several cultures, but with locally specific traits, such as [[penis panic]]s. A culture-specific syndrome is not the same as a geographically localized disease with specific, identifiable, causal tissue abnormalities, such as [[Kuru (disease)|kuru]] or [[African trypanosomiasis|sleeping sickness]], or genetic conditions limited to certain populations. It is possible that a condition originally assumed to be a culture-bound behavioral syndrome is found to have a biological cause; from a medical perspective it would then be redefined into another [[nosology|nosological]] category. ==Medical perspectives== The American Psychiatric Association states the following:{{Citation | author = American Psychiatric Association | title = Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 4th ed., text revision | publisher = American Psychiatric Pub | year = 2000 | page = 898 | isbn = 978-0-89042-025-6}}
The term ''culture-bound syndrome'' denotes recurrent, locality-specific patterns of aberrant behavior and troubling experience that may or may not be linked to a particular DSM-IV diagnostic category. Many of these patterns are indigenously considered to be "illnesses," or at least afflictions, and most have local names. Although presentations conforming to the major DSM-IV categories can be found throughout the world, the particular symptoms, course, and social response are very often influenced by local cultural factors. In contrast, culture-bound syndromes are generally limited to specific societies or culture areas and are localized, folk, diagnostic categories that frame coherent meanings for certain repetitive, patterned, and troubling sets of experiences and observations.
The term ''culture-bound syndrome'' is controversial since it reflects the different opinions of anthropologists and psychiatrists.Perry, S. (2012, 13 January). [http://www.minnpost.com/second-opinion/2012/01/controversy-over-culture-bound-mental-illnesses The controversy over 'culture-bound' mental illnesses]. Retrieved 27 January 2013 from MinnPost. Anthropologists have a tendency to emphasize the relativistic and culture-specific dimensions of the syndromes, while physicians tend to emphasize the universal and neuropsychological dimensions.Prince, Raymond H. (2000) ''In Review. Transcultural Psychiatry: Personal Experiences and Canadian Perspectives''. Canadian Journal of Psychiatry, 45: 431–437Jilek W.G (2001) ''Psychiatric Disorders: Culture-specific''. International Encyclopedia of the Social and Behavioral Sciences. Elsevier Science Ltd. Guarnaccia & Rogler (1999) have argued in favor of investigating culture-bound syndromes on their own terms, and believe that the syndromes have enough cultural integrity to be treated as independent objects of research.Guarnaccia, Peter J. & Rogler, Lloyd H. (1999) ''Research on Culture-Bound Syndromes: New Directions''. American Journal of Psychiatry 156:1322–1327, September Some studies suggest that culture-bound syndromes represent an acceptable way within a specific culture (and cultural context) among certain vulnerable individuals (i.e. an ''[[ataque de nervios]]'' at a funeral in Puerto Rico) to express distress in the wake of a traumatic experience.Schechter DS, Marshall RD, Salman E, Goetz D, Davies SO, Liebowitz MR (2000). Ataque de nervios and childhood trauma history: An association? Journal of Traumatic Stress, 13:3, 529–534. A similar manifestation of distress when displaced into a North American medical culture may lead to a very different, even adverse outcome for a given individual and [his or] her family.Schechter DS, Kaminer, T, Grienenberger JF, Amat J (2003). [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2078527/ Fits and starts: A mother-infant case study involving pseudoseizures across three generations in the context of violent trauma history] (with Commentaries by RD Marshall, CH Zeanah, T Gaensbauer). Infant Mental Health Journal. 24(5), 510–28. ==''DSM-IV-TR'' list== The fourth edition of ''Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders'' classifies the below syndromes as culture-bound syndromes:{{Citation | last = American Psychiatric Association | title = Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 4th ed., text revision | publisher = American Psychiatric Pub | year = 2000 | pages = 898–901 | isbn = 978-0-89042-025-6}} {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Name ! Geographical localization/populations |- | '''[[Running amok]]''' | [[Brunei]], [[Singapore]], [[Malaysia]], [[Indonesia]], [[Philippines]], [[Timor-Leste]] |- | '''[[Ataque de nervios]]''' | [[Hispanophone]], as well as in the [[Philippines]] where it is known as "nervous breakdown" |- | '''Bilis''', '''cólera''' | [[Latino]]s |- | '''[[Bouffée délirante]]''' | [[West Africa]] and [[Haiti]] |- | '''[[Brain fag syndrome]]''' | [[West African]] students |- | '''[[Dhat syndrome]]''' | [[Indian subcontinent|India]] |- | '''[[Falling-out]]''', '''blacking out''' | [[Southern United States]] and [[Caribbean]] |- | '''[[Ghost sickness]]''' | [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] |- | '''[[Hwabyeong]]''' | [[Korean people|Korean]] |- | '''[[Koro (medicine)|Koro]]''' | [[Han Chinese|Chinese]], [[Malaysian people|Malaysian]] and [[Indonesian people|Indonesian]] populations in [[Southeast Asia]]; [[Assam]]; occasionally in the [[Western world|West]] |- | '''[[Latah]]''' | [[Malaysia]], [[Indonesia]] and [[Philippines]] |- | '''[[Locura]]''' | [[Latino]]s in the [[United States]] and [[Latin America]] |- | '''[[Mal de pelea]]''' | [[Puerto Rico]] |- | '''[[Nervios]]''' | [[Latin America]], [[Latinos in the United States]], [[Philippines]] |- |- | '''[[Evil eye]]''' | [[Mediterranean]]; [[Hispanic]] populations and Ethiopia |- | '''[[Piblokto]]''' | Arctic and subarctic [[Inuit]] populations |- | '''[[Zou huo ru mo]] (Qigong psychotic reaction)''' | [[Han Chinese]] |- | '''[[Rootwork]]''' | Southern [[United States]], [[Caribbean]] nations |- | '''[[Sangue dormido]]''' | [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] populations in [[Cape Verde]] |- | '''[[Neurasthenia|Shenjing shuairuo]]''' | [[Han Chinese]] |- | '''[[Shenkui]], shen-kʼuei''' | [[Han Chinese]] |- | '''[[Shinbyeong]]''' | [[Korean people|Korean]] |- | '''[[Spell (trance)|Spell]]''' | [[African American]], [[White people|White]] populations in the [[southern United States]] and Ethiopia |- | '''[[Susto]]''' | [[Latino]]s in the [[United States]]; [[Mexico]], [[Central America]] and [[South America]] |- | '''[[Taijin kyofusho]]''' | [[Japanese people|Japanese]] |- | '''[[Zār]]''' | [[Ethiopia]], [[Somalia]], [[Egypt]], [[Sudan]], [[Iran]], and other [[North African]] and [[Middle Eastern]] societies |} == ''DSM-5'' list == The fifth edition of ''Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders'' classifies the below syndromes as cultural concepts of distress, a closely related concept:{{Citation | last = American Psychiatric Association | title = Diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders, 5th ed. | publisher = | year = 2013 | pages = 833–837 | isbn = 978-0-89042-554-1}} {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Name ! Geographical localization/populations |- | '''[[Ataque de nervios]]''' | [[Hispanophone]], as well as in the [[Philippines]] |- | '''[[Dhat syndrome]]''' | [[Indian subcontinent|India]] |- | '''[[Khyâl cap]]''' | [[Cambodian people|Cambodian]] |- | '''[[Ghost sickness]]''' | [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] |- | '''[[Kufungisisa]]''' | [[Zimbabwe]] |- | '''[[Maladi moun]]''' | [[Haiti]] |- | '''[[Nervios]]''' | [[Latin America]], [[Latinos in the United States]] |- | '''[[Neurasthenia|Shenjing shuairuo]]''' | [[Han Chinese]] |- | '''[[Susto]]''' | [[Latino]]s in the [[United States]]; [[Mexico]], [[Central America]] and [[South America]] |- | '''[[Taijin kyofusho]]''' | [[Japanese people|Japanese]] |} == ''ICD-10'' list == The 10th revision of the [[International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems]] (ICD) classifies the below syndromes as culture-specific disorders: {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Name ! Geographical localization/populations |- | '''[[Amok]]''' | [[Southeast Asia]]n [[Austronesian peoples|Austronesians]] |- | '''[[Dhat syndrome]] (dhātu), [[Shenkui|shen-kʼuei]], jiryan''' | [[India]]; [[Taiwan]] |- | '''[[Koro (medicine)|Koro]], suk yeong, jinjin bemar''' | [[Southeast Asia]], [[India]], [[China]] |- | '''[[Latah]]''' | [[Malaysia]] and [[Indonesia]] |- | '''[[Nervios]], nerfiza, nerves, nevra''' | [[Egypt]]; [[Greece]]; [[northern Europe]]; [[Mexico]], [[Central America|Central]] and [[South America]] |- | '''[[Pa-leng]] ([[frigophobia]])''' | [[Taiwan]]; [[Southeast Asia]] |- | '''[[Piblokto]]q (Arctic hysteria)''' | [[Inuit]] living within the [[Arctic Circle]] |- | '''[[Susto]], espanto''' | [[Mexico]], [[Central America|Central]] and [[South America]] |- | '''[[Taijin kyofusho]], shinkeishitsu ([[anthropophobia]])''' | [[Japan]] |- | '''[[Ufufuyane]], saka''' | [[Kenya]]; [[southern Africa]] (among [[Bantu peoples|Bantu]], [[Zulu people|Zulu]], and affiliated groups) |- | '''[[Uqamairineq]]''' | [[Inuit]] living within the Arctic Circle |- | '''Fear of [[Windigo]]''' | Indigenous people of north-east America |} ==Other examples== Within the contiguous United States, the consumption of [[kaolin]] has been proposed as a culture-bound syndrome observed in African Americans in the rural south, particularly in areas in which the mining of kaolin is common.South Med J. 1999;Feb 92 (2): 190-192. Chalk Eating in Middle Georgia: A Culture-Bound Syndrome of Pica? Grigsby, RK, Thyer, BA, Waller, RJ, Johnston, GA Jr In South Africa, among the [[Xhosa people]], the syndrome [[amafufunyana]] is commonly used to describe those believed to be possessed by demons or other malevolent spirits. Traditional healers in the culture usually perform exorcisms in order to drive off these spirits. Upon investigating the phenomenon, researchers found that many of the people claimed to be affected by the syndrome exhibited the traits and characteristics of [[schizophrenia]].{{cite journal |vauthors=Niehaus DJ, Oosthuizen P, Lochner C, Emsley RA, Jordaan E, Mbanga NI, Keyter N, Laurent C, Deleuze JF, Stein DJ |date=March–April 2004 |title=A culture-bound syndrome 'amafufunyana' and a culture-specific event 'ukuthwasa': differentiated by a family history of schizophrenia and other psychiatric disorders |journal=[[Psychopathology (journal)|Psychopathology]] |publisher=[[Karger Publishers]] |volume=37 |issue=2 |pages=59–63 |doi=10.1159/000077579 |pmid=15057028 }}]] [[Vegetative-vascular dystonia]] can be considered an example of somatic condition formally recognised by local medical community in former Soviet Union countries, but not in Western classification systems. Its [[umbrella term]] nature as neurological condition also results in diagnosing neurotic patients as neurological ones,{{cite journal |vauthors=Mikhaylov, B |date=2010 |title= P02-34 -Statistical issues of the psychiatric care in Ukraine |url=http://www.europsy-journal.com/article/S0924-9338(10)70647-7/abstract |journal=European Psychiatry|volume=25|pages=652 |doi=10.1016/S0924-9338(10)70647-7 |accessdate=October 2, 2016 }}EPA-1025 - Integrative psychotherapy model of anxiety disorders Mykhaylov, B. et al. European Psychiatry, Volume 29, 1 http://www.europsy-journal.com/article/S0924-9338(14)78319-1/abstract in effect substituting possible psychiatric stigma with culture-bound syndrome disguised as a neurological condition. Refugee children in Sweden have been known to fall into coma-like states on learning their families will be deported. The condition, known as Uppgivenhetssyndrom, or [[Resignation Syndrome|resignation syndrome]] is believed to only exist among the refugee population in the Scandinavian country, where it has been prevalent since the early part of the 21st Century. In a hundred-and-thirty-page report on the condition, commissioned by the government and published in 2006, a team of psychologists, political scientists, and sociologists hypothesized that it was a culture-bound syndrome, a psychological illness endemic to a specific society.{{cite news|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/04/03/the-trauma-of-facing-deportation|title=The Trauma of Facing Deportation|author=Rachel Aviv|date=April 3, 2017|work=The New Yorker|accessdate=1 July 2017}} ==See also== {{col div|colwidth=30em}} * [[Cross-cultural psychiatry]] * [[Cross-cultural psychology]] * [[Hikikomori]] * [[Hi-wa itck]] * [[Medical anthropology]] * [[Neurasthenia]] * [[Hakuin Ekaku#Zen sickness|Zen sickness]] {{colend}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * {{citation |year=1991 |author=[[Arthur Kleinman|Kleinman, Arthur]] |title=Rethinking psychiatry: from cultural category to personal experience |place=New York |publisher=Free Press |isbn= 0-02-917441-4 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bY6f7ebzTvYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22Rethinking+psychiatry%22#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=8 January 2011}} * {{citation |year=1977 |editor=Landy, David |title=Culture, Disease, and Healing: Studies in Medical Anthropology |place=New York |publisher=Macmillan |isbn=978-0-02-367390-0 }} * {{citation |year=2003 |author=John Launer |title=Folk illness and medical models |journal=Q J Med |volume=96 |issue=11 |pages=875–876 |url=http://qjmed.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/full/96/11/875 |doi=10.1093/qjmed/hcg136}} * {{citation |year=1985 |editor=[[Ronald C. Simons|Simons, Rondald C]] |editor2=Hughes, Charles C |title=The Culture-Bound Syndromes: Folk Illnesses and Anthropological Interest |place=Dordrecht, Holland |publisher=D. Reidel Publishing Co |isbn=90-277-1858-X|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nMQQ7-AR1dYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=culture-bound#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=9 September 2010}} Paperback {{ISBN|90-277-1859-8}} * {{citation |year=2004 |author=Rebhun, L.A |chapter=Culture-Bound Syndromes |pages=319–327 |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=JI9IsHAbsnsC&pg=PA319&dq=culture-bound&hl=en&ei=1GSITMfnGpTSuwPDwJ0B&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=culture-bound&f=false |editor1=Ember, Carol R. |editor2=Ember, Melvin |title=Encyclopedia of Medical Anthropology: Health and Illness in the World's Cultures |place=New York |publisher=Klower Academic/Plenum Publishers |isbn=0-306-47754-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nrMRezmNrPcC&printsec=frontcover&dq=medical+anthropology+ember#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=9 September 2010}} (Note: Different preview pages result in the full chapter being viewable from the title link). * {{citation |year=2001 |author=Kirmayer, L. J. |title=Cultural variations in the clinical presentation of depression and anxiety: implications for diagnosis and treatment. |journal=Journal of Clinical Psychiatry |volume=62 |pages=22–30 }} == External links == * [http://www.psychiatrictimes.com/p011163.html Psychiatric Times – Introduction to Culture-Bound Syndromes]{{registration required}} * [http://business.highbeam.com/5799/article-1G1-17782626/culturebound-syndromes-fakery Skeptical Inquirer – Culture-bound syndromes as fakery] {{DEFAULTSORT:Culture-Bound Syndrome}} [[Category:Culture-bound syndromes| ]] [[Category:Medical anthropology]]
