{{Infobox Korean name |hangul= 대종교 |hanja= {{linktext|大|倧|敎|}} |rr= Daejonggyo |mr= Taejonggyo }} [[File:Daejongism symbol.svg|thumb|150px|The symbol of Dangunism.]] '''Daejongism''' ({{lang-ko|대종교|大倧敎}} ''Daejonggyo'' or ''Taejongkyo'', "religion of the Divine Progenitor"<ref name=religions>{{cite book|last1=Chang|first1=Yunshik|last2=Hyun-Ho|first2=Seok|last3=Baker|first3=Donald L.|title=Korea confronts globalization|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3-HxKjWqMEMC&pg=PA211|series=Routledge Advances in Korean Studies|volume=14|year=2008|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=0-415-45879-X|pages=211–212|chapter=Globalization and Korea's new religions}}</ref> or "great ancestral religion"<ref name=empires>{{cite book|last=Schmid|first=Andre|title=Korea between empires, 1895-1919|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oSXtk6uxrhgC|series=Studies of the East Asian Institute|year=2002|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=0-231-12539-9}}</ref>{{rp|192}}) or '''Dangunism''' ({{lang-ko|단군교|檀君敎}} ''Dangungyo'' or ''Tangunkyo'', "religion of Dangun")<ref>[http://www.daejonggyo.or.kr/modules/board/bd_view.html?id=qna&no=5 Daejonggyo, national religion of Korea]. Quote: «''A great scholar of the Silla Dynasty Choe Chi-weon (857-? A.D.), naturally wrote that Dangunism (Dae-jong-Gyo), a religious teaching indigenous to Korea, embraces the essential teachings of Taoism, Buddhism and Confucianism.''»</ref> is the name of a number of religious movements within the framework of [[Korean shamanism]], focused on the worship of [[Dangun]] (or Tangun). There are around seventeen of these groups, the main one of which was founded in [[Seoul]] in 1909 by Na Cheol ([[:ko:나철|나철]], 1864-1916).<ref name=religions/><ref name=koreas/><ref>[http://preview.britannica.co.kr/bol/topic.asp?article_id=b03n2772a 한국브리태니커 온라인 - 나철] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20140918143841/http://preview.britannica.co.kr/bol/topic.asp?article_id=b03n2772a |date=2014-09-18 }} Encyclopædia Britannica online Korea 'Na Cheol'</ref>
Dangunists believe their [[myth]]os to be the authentic Korean [[native religion]], that was already around as ''Gosindo'' (古神道, "way of the Ancestral God" or "ancient way of God") at the time of the first [[Mongol invasions of Korea]], and that was revived as "Daejongism" (''Daejonggyo'') just at the start of the [[Korea under Japanese rule|Japanese occupation]].<ref>Lee Chi-ran, pp. 11-12</ref> The religion was suppressed during the Japanese rule.<ref name="Lee Chi-ran, p. 12">Lee Chi-ran, p. 12</ref>
The religion believes in one God manifested in three persons,<ref name="Baker (2007a), p. 464.">Baker (2007a), p. 464.</ref> whose earthly incarnation was the legendary king [[Dangun]], who ruled over a Korean empire around 5000 years ago.<ref name=religions/> Its main tenet is that the Koreans have their own God and they have no need to worship foreign gods.<ref name=spirituality/> Its emphasis is on the national identity and unity of the [[Korean people]] (known as ''[[wiktionary:민족|minjok]]'') and as such has been associated with [[Korean nationalism]] (and sometimes ultranationalism).<ref name=empires/>{{rp|193}}
Daejongism does not focus so much on institutions or rituals but rather on central doctrines and associated mythologies, so that it is more definable as a creed or a faith system rather than an organized religion. In the decade of 1910-1920, it had its major growth, reaching an estimated following of 400,000.<ref name="Lee Gyungwon, p. 54.">Lee Gyungwon, p. 54.</ref> Its popularity was largely due to its efforts on behalf of Korean independence. Once this aim was achieved, its membership declined, although Daejongism acquired a reputation for its educational and scholarly institutions, which published in particular monumental works about Korea's struggle for independence and Daejongism's contribution to it.<ref name="Lee Gyungwon, p. 67.">Lee Gyungwon, p. 67.</ref> A 1995 census found that fewer than 10,000 Koreans claimed to follow the religion.,<ref name=koreas>{{cite book|last=Connor|first=Mary E.|title=The Koreas|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j2gYgXGENM0C&pg=PA173|series=Asia in focus|year=2009|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=1-59884-160-2|page=173|chapter=Society}}</ref> although Korean census figures systematically underestimate the number of followers of new religions, who are often reluctant to indicate their religious affiliation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Baker|first=Don|date=September 2006|title=The Religious Revolution in Modern Korean History: From ethics to theology and from ritual hegemony to religious freedom|journal=The Review of Korean Studies|publisher=The Academy of Korean Studies|volume=9|issue=3|pages=249–275}}</ref>
==Teaching== Central to the faith is the belief in [[Haneullim]], the triad of Gods of Korean culture: the creator (Hanim/[[Hwanin]]), the teacher (Hanung/[[Hwanung]]) and the ruler (Dangun/Hanbaegŏm).<ref name=religions/><ref name=spirituality>{{cite book|last=Baker|first=Donald L.|title=Korean spirituality|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RCBe9w9C2UkC&pg=PA118|year=2008|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|isbn=0-8248-3233-7|page=118}}</ref> Dangun, the leader of the Korean nation, is thought to be the third, and human, manifestation of Haneullim ("God of Heaven") or Haneul ("Heaven").<ref name="Lee Chi-ran, p. 12"/> His physical mother was [[Ungnye]] (熊女) a bear transformed into a woman.<ref name="Lee Chi-ran, p. 13">Lee Chi-ran, p. 13</ref>
After his earthly reign, Dangun ascended to Heaven.<ref name="Lee Chi-ran, p. 13"/> Semantically, Haneul connotes three Gods: God-Father as the creator of the universe, God-Teacher as the mentor of universal nature and God-King as ruler of creation.<ref>Lee Chi-ran, p. 14</ref>
The faith is embodied in three sacred texts. Believers claim that they date back to the time of Dangun, or even earlier, and this claim, although disputed by scholars, is also accepted by many Koreans who do not belong to Daejongism.<ref name="Baker (2007a), p. 465.">Baker (2007a), p. 465.</ref> The three texts are the ''Ch'ónbugong'' (The Classic of the Seal of Heaven), a narrative of the origins of the world, the ''Samil sin'go'' (The Teachings of the Triune God), a theological statement, and the ''Ch'amjóngyóng'' (The Classic of the Wise One), a manual of ethics.<ref name="Baker (2007a), p. 465.">Baker (2007a), p. 465.</ref> A number of scholars believe that these books were compiled in the first two decades of the 20th century, based on visions and revelation the founder of Daejongism, Na Cheol (1863-1916), claimed to have received<ref name="Lee Gyungwon, p. 39.">Lee Gyungwon, p. 39.</ref>
Daejongism is also well-known for its teaching of breathing techniques, known in the West as part of the so called internal alchemy ([[Neidan]] in [[Taoism]]). Daejongism's techniques focus on the '"sea of energy," which is also often referred to as the cinnabar field or the elixir field (''tanjón'').The ''tanjon'' is a field rich in the vital energy [[Qi]] and the religion offers techniques to draw on this field and circulate the energy through the human body. These techniques became extremely popular in the 1970s and generated a new interest in Daejongism and its school of internal alchemy, known as Kich'ónmun.<ref name="Baker (2007b), p. 508.">Baker (2007b), p. 508.</ref>
==Samsin Sinang== Samsin Sinang is a Dangunist sect.<ref name="Lee Chi-ran, p. 16">Lee Chi-ran, p. 16</ref> Its headquarters are in [[Pyeongchang County]].<ref name="Lee Chi-ran, p. 16"/> The current leader is Bae Sun-moon, and the religion promotes the [[Korean reunification]].<ref name="Lee Chi-ran, p. 16"/>
==History and influences== [[File:Na_cheol.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Na Cheol, the founder of the religion.]] Na Cheol, known for his role as a leader of the [[Korean independence movement]] from Japanese rule, founded the religion in 1909 as its "great teacher" (''tosagyo'')<ref name=sources/> and named it first "Dangunism" (''Dangungyo'', [[Dangun]] religion) and then a year later "Daejongism" (''Daejonggyo'').<ref name=religions/><ref name=empires/>{{rp|192}}
He said that it was a revival of ''Goshindo'' (古神道, "way of the Ancestral God"),<ref name="Lee Chi-ran, p. 12"/> the belief in the [[Haneullim|trinitarian god]] that was worshipped in ancient [[Korea]]. Some scholars have suggested the affinity to [[Christianity]], though the ethical basis of the religion is similar to [[Confucianism]].<ref name=religions/>
The importance of [[Dangun]] was influenced by [[Shin Chaeho]]'s ''A New Reading of History'', and Dangun was emphasised over another legendary figure, [[Jizi]] (Kija), who was said to not be Korean in origin.<ref name=empires/>{{rp|192}} Na claimed that the ''Goshindo'' religion was approximately 4300 years of age, which would make it Korea's oldest religion.
After the [[annexation of Korea]] in 1910 by the [[Empire of Japan]], the new religion was spread in [[Manchuria]] by Na, where it set up schools and social centers, and became a focus of the Korean independence movement.<ref name=empires/>{{rp|193}} Na committed suicide at a shrine on [[Kuwolsan|Mount Kuwŏl]] in 1916, saying that he had guilt over his failures and was martyring himself for the sake of his religion, God and people.<ref name=sources>{{cite book|last1=Ch'oe|first1=Yongho|last2=Lee|first2=Peter H.|last3=De Bary|first3=William Theodore|title=Sources of Korean Tradition: From the sixteenth to the twentieth centuries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A9LoA9L1ABcC&pg=PA331|series=Introduction to Asian civilizations: Sources of Korean Tradition|volume=2|year=2000|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=0-231-12031-1|page=331}}</ref>
Leaders of the religion after Na include his successor Kim Kyohong,<ref name=empires/>{{rp|50}} and An Ho-Sang.<ref name=religions/> The teachings of Dangun were said by Kim in his "History of the Divine Dangun's People" to be the ''sin gyo'' or "divine teaching", and he said that various Korean religions, such as that of [[Wang Kon]], were continuations of the ''sin gyo'', but that these beliefs had been suppressed under the [[Mongols]], [[Buddhism]], and [[Confucianism]].<ref name=empires/>{{rp|194}}<ref name=spirituality/> The main task of the religion was ''chunggwang'' ("lighting anew"), meaning reviving the memory of Dangun.<ref name=empires/>{{rp|198}}
A particularly controversial issue concerns the roots in Daejongism of the global physical exercise and spirituality system known as [[Body & Brain]], Dahnhak, or Dahn Yoga, founded by Korean master of martial arts and author [[Ilchi Lee]]. While "Body and Brain" does not normally emphasize its connection with Daejongism, scholars see it as one of many schools teaching a form of internal alchemy based on the techniques Daejongism popularized. According to American scholar of Korean religion Don Baker, "not only-did Dahn claim that its techniques were the same practices that Tàn'gun [Dangun] taught when he ruled over the first Korean kingdom; it also heralded the three Tàn'gun-era sacred texts of Taejonggyo [Daejongism] as authentic scripture." Only when the movement became international, references to Dangun and Daejongism were downplayed, although the [[c:File:Daejongism_symbol.svg|Daejongism symbol]] was embroidered on the original uniforms given to Dahnhak students in America and the organization "erected a large outdoor statue of Tan'gun near [its] Sedona [Arizona] headquarters." Baker states that references to Daejongism, although not made explicit, remain easy to detect for those familiar with the Korean religion.<ref name="Baker (2007b), p. 509.">Baker (2007b), p. 509.</ref>

The '''Dana Point Concours d'Elegance''' is an automotive charitable event held each year on the [[Monarch Beach, Dana Point, California|Monarch Beach]] Golf Links at the Monarch Beach Resort Resort in [[Dana Point, California]]. It is operated primarily as a Classic Car Club of America (CCCA) [[Concours d'Elegance|Concours]], with additional classes showcasing interesting and relevant automobiles and motorcycles. The 2010 event was held Sunday, June 27, 2010 moving from its traditional date in September.<ref>{{Cite press release| title = Dana Point Concours d'Elegance Announces 2010 Event Date & Name Change | publisher = Dana Point Concours d'Elegance| date = January 15, 2010| url = http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/dana-point-concours-delegance-announces-2010-event-date--name-change-81727517.html| accessdate = February 5, 2010}} </ref>
A ''[[Concours d'Elegance]]'' ([[French language|French]], literally "a competition of elegance") is an event open to both prewar and postwar collector cars in which they are judged for authenticity, function, history, and style. Classes are commonly arranged by type, marque (manufacturer), [[coachbuilder]], country of origin, or time period. Judges select first-, second-, and third-place finishers for each class in the event, and the judges confer the "Best of Show" award on one car from the group of first-place winners. In addition, a group of honorary judges, individuals who have made significant contributions to the automotive industry or motorsports, award a number of subjective awards to recognize standout vehicles regardless of class ribbons, as well as memorial awards created to honor specific automotive industry personages.
==History== The first Concours was held in 1983 and was known as the Newport Beach Concours d'Elegance. It was held on the campus of [[University of California, Irvine]] for the first 10 years before moving to Pelican Hill Resort. In 2008 the event moved to the Monarch Beach Golf Links at the Monarch Beach Resort in Dana Point and in 2010 the Concours organizing committee officially changed the name of the event to the Dana Point Concours d'Elegance to properly reflect its new home.<ref name="scm0910">{{cite journal|last=Osborne|first=Donald|title=Dana Point Concours d'Elegance|journal=[[Sports Car Market]]|date=September 2010|volume=22|issue=9|page=38}}</ref>
Each year's Dana Point Concours honors a featured marque, coachbuilder, type or classification: *2010: [[Alfa Romeo]] & [[Pininfarina]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Degen|first=Matt|title=Ode to automotive excellence lures thousands|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/year-255270-vintage-concours.html|accessdate=28 June 2010|newspaper=[[The Orange County Register]]|date=June 28, 2010}}</ref> *2009: [[Mercedes-Benz]] & [[Aston Martin]] *2008: [[Cadillac]] *2007: 25 Years of Cars *2006: [[Mercedes-Benz]] *2005: [[Ferrari]] *2004: [[Rolls-Royce Motor Cars|Rolls Royce]] & [[Bentley]] *2003: [[Packard]] *2002: [[Aston Martin]] *2001: [[Jaguar Cars|Jaguar]] *2000: [[Lincoln (automobile)|Lincoln]] *1999: [[Packard]] *1998: British Sports Racing Cars *1997: French Coachbuilders *1996: German Automotive Heritage *1995: Italian Cars *1994: British Auto Masterpieces *1993: Antiques *1992: American Classics *1991: [[Mercedes-Benz]] *1990: [[Cadillac]] *1989: [[Ferrari]] *1988: [[Pierce-Arrow]] *1987: French Classics *1986: [[Duesenberg]] *1985: [[Rolls-Royce Motors|Rolls Royce]] *1984: [[Packard]] *1983: [[Bugatti Royale]]
History of locations: *2008–present: Monarch Beach Golf Links at the Monarch Beach Resort, [[Dana Point, CA]] *2004–2007: Strawberry Farms Golf Club, [[Irvine, CA]] *2002–2005: Hidden Valley Park, [[Irvine, CA]] *2000–2001: The Oaks, [[San Juan Capistrano, CA]] *1994–1999: [[Pelican Hill]] Golf Club, [[Newport Coast, CA]] *1983–1993: University of California, [[Irvine, CA]]
==Exhibitors== Prospective entrants must submit an application for each car, and the Concours field is selected from each year's pool of applicants. Entrants also come from some of Southern California's leading car collections such as the [[Nethercutt Collection]] and [[Petersen Automotive Museum]].<ref name="scm0910"/>
Best of Show winners by year: *2010: 1929 [[Auburn Automobile|Auburn]] 8-120 Boattail *2009: 1951 [[Delahaye 235]] Roadster *2008: 1937 [[Talbot-Lago]] T150-C-S Sport Coupe *2007: 1931 [[Cadillac V-16|Cadillac Sport Phaeton V-16 Fleetwood]] *2006: 1936 [[Delahaye]] 135 Competition Convertible *2005: 1934 [[Duesenberg]] Walker LeGrande J534 Covertible *2004: 1912 [[Rolls-Royce Silver Ghost]] *2003: 1932 [[Bugatti Type 49|Bugatti Type 49 Cabriolet]] *2002: 1937 [[Mercedes-Benz 540K|Mercedes-Benz 540K Special Roadster]] *2001: 1914 [[Rolls-Royce Silver Ghost|Rolls-Royce Silver Ghost Skiff]] *2000: 1931 [[Duesenberg]] J Boattail Speedster *1999: 1939 [[Packard]] 1708 Sport Phaeton *1998: 1961 [[Aston Martin DB4 GT Zagato]] *1997: 1934 [[Avions Voisin|Voisin]] C27 Figoni [[Cabriolet]] *1996: 1906 [[Panhard]] Double Phaeton *1995: 1930 [[Isotta Fraschini]] 8A SS Castagna *1994: 1929 [[Rolls-Royce Limited|Rolls Royce]] P11 Brewster Town car *1993: 1909 [[Winton Motor Carriage Company|Winton]] 17 Touring *1992: 1939 [[Delahaye]] Type 165 Figoni et Falashi *1991: 1939 [[Mercedes-Benz 770|Mercedes-Benz 770 K Cabriolet B]] *1990: 1931 [[Bugatti Type 51|Bugatti Type 54 O-Uhlik Roadster]] *1989: 1922 [[Hispano-Suiza H6|Hispano-Suiza H6B Labourdette Skiff]] *1988: 1936 [[Mercedes-Benz 540K|Mercedes-Benz 540K Roadster]] *1987: 1939 [[Delage]] D8 120 Letourneur Sport [[Cabriolet]] *1986: 1931 [[Cadillac]] 452 Fleetwood Sport Phaeton *1985: 1930 [[Duesenberg]] J Boattail Speedster *1984: 1930 [[Cadillac V-16|Cadillac V-16 Roadster]] *1983: 1935 [[Mercedes-Benz 500K]]
==Charitable giving== The excess proceeds of the Dana Point Concours d'Elegance support the [[Ocean Institute]], the Mary & Dick Allen Diabetes Center at Hoag Hospital as well as other Southern California youth charities.

revision.text:
'''Dau al Set''' ({{IPA-ca|ˈdaw əl ˈsɛt}}), the first post-[[World War II]] artistic movement in [[Catalonia]], was founded in [[Barcelona]] in September 1948 by poet [[Joan Brossa]]. The movement, best known for translating the conscious and unconscious mind into art, was heavily influenced by both the [[Surrealism|Surrealist]] and [[Dada]]ist movements. In [[Catalan language|Catalan]] Dau al Set means "the seventh face of the dice", which expresses the movement's rupturist character.
== History == Dau al Set first began as an [[avant-garde]] artistic collective led by [[Joan Brossa]], a Catalan poet, in September 1948. [[Joan Brossa]] established the group in response to the period’s conservative reigning government, which gained power after the [[Spanish Civil War]] known as the "[[:es:Guerra Civil Española|Guerra Civil]]". Under the new [[Fascism|fascist]] regime, [[Francisco Franco]] radically changed many areas of the previous culture. One such example was the Spanish art community as seen in [[art and culture in Francoist Spain]]. During this time counterculture movements in Catalonia and Spain in general came to an abrupt halt.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.macba.cat/en/revista-dau-al-set-modest-cuixart-2016|title=Revista Dau al Set. Modest Cuixart|website=www.macba.cat|access-date=2016-05-30}}</ref> Such artistic groups were replaced with [[Art and culture in Francoist Spain|Nationalist Fascist Art]], which often functioned as a means for government endorsement and propaganda. In an attempt to revive the avant-garde scene in Spain Dau al Set was formed.
In 1949, with help from [[Joan-Josep Tharrats]]'s private printing press, Dau al Set published its first self-entitled magazine journal. The majority of the publication was written in [[Catalan language|Catalan]], a language prohibited under the [[Francoist Spain|Franco Regime]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Cirlot|first=Lourdes|date=December 2008|title=El grupo Dau al Set|url=http://www.triarte.es/catalogos/Cat%20Dau%20al%20Set.pdf|journal=El Mundo de Dau al Set|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Dau al Set typically ran a print between one hundred and two hundred copies,<ref name=":0" /> consisting of four to twelve pages.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Franco Lahoz|first=Amado|date=December 2008|title=Sumario de la revista Dau al Set|url=http://www.triarte.es/catalogos/Cat%20Dau%20al%20Set.pdf|journal=El Mundo de Dau al Set|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> The magazine journal was delivered throughout Barcelona to those with subscriptions and served a niche population at the time. The format of the magazine was 22.5 cm x 18.7 cm in the [[broadsheet]] style and never bound.<ref name=":1" /> These publications continued on a regular basis until the end of 1951 at which point Dau al Set began to dissolve.
In 1952, Dau al Set founding member [[Antoni Tàpies]] left the group to promote his own independent work in the [[Surrealism|Surrealist]] and [[Informalism|Informal]] art styles. The following year [[Joan Ponç]] left to Brazil to continue to paint and spread his unique style. And one year later [[Modest Cuixart|Modest Cuixcart]] left the group as well. During this time from 1953 till 1956 Dau al Set continued to be created and published by Joan-Josep Tharrats.<ref name=":1" /> During the final years the magazine decreased from an issue a month to an issue every season to then two issues a year. The final issue was created and distributed in 1956.<ref name=":2" />
== Style == Initially, Dau al Set began as an offshoot of [[Surrealism]], but slowly grew into a distinct style with many existing components. One such component began with the incorporation of the surrealist world of dreams, where in Dau al Set expands upon by combing scientific and philosophical articles with magical undertones derived from [[Joan Brossa|Joan Brossa's]] personalized style.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://lletra.uoc.edu/ca/revista/dau-al-set-1948-1956/detall|title=Dau al Set (1948-1956) - lletrA - Literatura catalana a internet|last=Catalunya|first=Universitat Oberta de|website=lletra.uoc.edu|language=ca|access-date=2016-05-30}}</ref> The use of magical elements pervaded throughout the entire movement to showcase an esoteric world of inner exploration.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.elcultural.com/revista/arte/Dau-al-set/14686|title=Dau al set|website=www.elcultural.com|access-date=2016-05-30}}</ref> While magic was seen consistently the different members each contributed a unique style to Dau al Set. One of the most drastic was the contributions from [[Joan Ponç]]. Ponç's art frequently contained demonic images actualized with a series of different monsters throughout the work.<ref name=":1" /> In contrast, [[Modest Cuixart|Modest Cuixart's]] work often contained images of fantasy influenced by [[German Expressionism|German expressionism]] and [[Joan Miró]].<ref name=":1" /> Finally, [[Antoni Tàpies|Antoni Tápies]] often emulated the style of [[Paul Klee]] with obscure images surrounded by a dark atmosphere and phosphorescent lighting. With the base of magical elements these three unique techniques joined together to create the style seen in the Dau al Set movement.
== Influences == Dau al Set was heavily influenced by two movements before its creation, those two being [[Dada]]ism and [[Surrealism]]. Dadaism was a European art movement in the early 20th century which focused on the avant-garde. This style was meant to fight against the [[Bourgeoisie|bourgeois]] in society with the belief that their reason and logic were the cause of war. With an anti-reason and anti-logic sentiment most of the works of art often contained elements of chaos and irrationality. Dadaist art also utilized the following techniques of [[cubism]], [[collage]]s, [[cut-up technique]], [[photomontage]]s, and [[Assemblage (art)|assemblage]] which can be seen in Dau al Set's work. From this movement spawned the pre-war avant-garde which was the community Dau al Set were trying to revive. Some influential artists on Dau al Set from this movement are [[Francis Picabia]] and [[Max Ernst]].
Another influence on Dau al Set was [[Surrealism]], a cultural movement greatly influenced by Dadaism, which began in the 1920s. This style was often considered a portrayal of the dream world; a reality which existed right below everyday life. It also had a large political focus which was often used to contradict a given community's social norms often imposed by the bourgeois. Some artists from this movement that influenced Dau al Set were [[Joan Miró]], [[Paul Klee]], [[Josep Vicenç Foix]], and [[Salvador Dalí]].<ref name=":0" /> Other methods that were influenced was the idea of magical aspects that were often seen in the dream world surrealism created. However, in Dau al Set these magical aspects were developed and expounded upon.
== Members == There were six founding members of Dau al Set including a poet [[Joan Brossa]], a philosopher [[Arnau Puig]], three artists [[Joan Ponç]], [[Antoni Tàpies]], and [[Modest Cuixart]], as well as a dual painter and editor [[Joan-Josep Tharrats]].
Over the years Dau al Set ran there were occasional contributors, such as [[Juan Eduardo Cirlot]], [[Antonio Saura]], [[Enrique Tábara]], and [[Manolo Millares]]. Their contributions came often in the form of writings which helped to continued to establish Dau al Set as an intellectual piece of work.<ref name=":0" />
== Exhibitions == Dau al Set actively participated in the exhibition at the Institut Francais and the Sala Caralt. * December 1949, Institut Francais in Barcelona, Spain * October 1951, Sala Caralt in Barcelona, Spain * December 2008-January 2009 Fundacio J.V. Foix in Barcelona, Spain * February 2009- April 2009, Fundacio Fran Daurel in Barcelona, Spain * May 2009-June 2009, University of Cantabria in Santander, Spain * July 2009-August 2009, Fundacion Diaz Caneja in Palencia, Spain * August 2009- September 2009, Fundacion Antonio Perez in Cuenca, Spain * October 2009-December 2009, Ibercaja in Zaragoza, Spain * December 2009-January 2010, Sala de Exposiciones Vimcorsa in Cordoba, Spain * February 2010-March 2010, Museo de Arte Contemporáneo Conde Duque in Madrid, Spain * April 2010-May 2010, Centro Cultural de la Diputación in Ourense, Spain * May 2010-June 2010, Sala Pescadería Vieja in Jerez de la Frontera, Spain
== Impact == Dau al Set has had a lasting impact throughout history the most notable being the continuation of the avant-garde in Spain throughout a repressive regime. Moreover, Dau al Set contributed to the creation of the [[Informalism|Informalist]] movement seen in Spain during the fifties.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.arteespana.com/grupodaualset.htm|title=Grupo Dau al Set|website=www.arteespana.com|access-date=2016-05-30}}</ref> Also the magical and fantasy elements of Dau al Set was seen to later emerge again in Spain in the eighties.<ref name=":1" />
This group also stood as a large influence for other artistic movements in Spain such as the [[Grup d'Elx|Grup d’Elx]] and El Paso, with important artists such as [[Joan Castejón]], [[Eusebio Sempere]] or [[Manolo Millares]]. Additionally, each of the members made their own impacts after the movement was dissolved. Most notably is [[Antoni Tàpies]] who continued with his style based heavily in surrealism and later became a notable artist for his work in Abstract art.

This article is about the [[demographics|demographic]] features of the [[population]] of [[Botswana]], including [[population density]], [[Ethnic group|ethnicity]], education level, health of the populace, economic status, religious affiliations and other aspects of the population.
[[Image:Botswana-demography.svg|thumb|300px|right|Demographics of Botswana, Data of [[Food and Agriculture Organization|FAO]], year 2008; Number of inhabitants in thousands.]] [[Image:Botswanahouse.jpg|thumb|250px|A type of house in Botswana]]
[[Botswana]], like many nations in southern [[Africa]], suffers from a high [[HIV]] infection rate, estimated among adults ages 15 to 49 to be 24.8%.<ref name=avert>{{cite web | title =HIV & Aids in Botswana|publisher=AVERT International HIV & Aids Charity|url = http://www.avert.org/aids-botswana.htm|accessdate=15 January 2013}}</ref>
==Population==
===Census results=== {{Historical populations | title=Botswana Population and Housing Census | percentages = pagr | 1904 |120776 | 1911 |124350 | 1921 |152983 | 1936 |265756 | 1946 |296310 | 1956 |309175 | 1964 |549510 | 1971 |596994 | 1981 |941027 | 1991 |1326796 | 2001 |1680863 | 2011 |2024787 | footnote=<ref name=history /><ref name="indicators">{{cite web |title=TABLE 1: 1971, 1981, 1991 and 2001 CENSUS DEMOGRAPHIC INDICATORS; BOTSWANA |url=http://www.cso.gov.bw/templates/cso/file/File/Table_1971-2001_Census_Demographic_Indicators(1).pdf |publisher=Central Statistics Office |accessdate=20 July 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69I3pDlJb?url=http://www.cso.gov.bw/templates/cso/file/File/Table_1971-2001_Census_Demographic_Indicators(1).pdf |archivedate=20 July 2012 |location=Gaborone |page=1 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name=2011Census>{{cite web |title=The Population of Towns, Villages and Associated Localities |work=2011 Population and Housing Census |url=http://www.cso.gov.bw/templates/cso/file/File/Population%20of%20Towns%20and%20Villages%20_2011%20PHC_%20Jun%204%202012..pdf |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68QAYaEFm?url=http://www.cso.gov.bw/templates/cso/file/File/Population%20of%20Towns%20and%20Villages%20_2011%20PHC_%20Jun%204%202012..pdf |archivedate=14 June 2012 |accessdate=20 July 2012 |date=June 2012 |publisher=Statistics Botswana |location=Gaborone |format=PDF |page=1 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> }}
====Bechuanaland Protectorate==== The seven censuses of Botswana before its independence happened irregularly. Due to the [[Second Boer War|Anglo-Boer War]], the first census of [[Bechuanaland Protectorate]], originally set to occur in 1901, took place on 17 April 1904.<ref name="history">{{cite web|title=History|url=http://www.cso.gov.bw/index.php?option=com_content1&site=census&id=28&parent_id=27|publisher=Central Statistics Office|accessdate=20 July 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69I1Cikab?url=http://www.cso.gov.bw/index.php?option=com_content1&site=census&id=28&parent_id=27|archivedate=20 July 2012|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> The 1931 census was postponed to 1936 because of the [[Great Depression]].<ref name=history /> The early censuses were unreliable and took several years to tabulate; the results were outdated by the time they were calculated.
====Post-independence==== There have been five censuses after the independence of Botswana, each occurring every ten years in the year ending in 1 (i.e. 1971, 1981, 1991, 2001, and 2011). The 1971 census was the first census in Botswana to use de facto enumeration; this method counts people based on how many people spent census night at a specific location. Previously, the citizens were counted based on their usual place of residence. The 2001 census was the first census in Botswana to comply with the [[Southern African Development Community|SADC]] 2000 Census Project, the guidelines of which unify the demographic statistics in southern [[Africa]]. The most recent census was the [[2011 Botswana Population and Housing Census]], which occurred in August 2011.
===UN estimates=== According to {{UN_Population|source}} the total population was {{UN_Population|Botswana}} in {{UN_Population|Year}}, compared to only 413,000 in 1950. The proportion of children below the age of 15 in 2010 was 32.6%, 63.4% was between 15 and 65 years of age, while 4% was 65 years or older.<ref name="WPP 2010">{{cite web|url=http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp/index.htm|title=Population Division of the Department of Economic and Social Affairs of the United Nations Secretariat, World Population Prospects: The 2010 Revision|author=|date=|website=un.org|accessdate=15 April 2018}}</ref> [[Image:Botswana population pyramid 2005.png|thumb|250px|[[Population pyramid]]]] {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: right;" |- ! ! width="80pt"|Total population ! width="80pt"|Population aged 0–14 (%) ! width="80pt"|Population aged 15–64 (%) ! width="80pt"|Population aged 65+ (%) |- | 1950 | 413 000||40.9||54.8||4.4 |- | 1955 | 470 000||42.4||53.4||4.2 |- | 1960 | 524 000||45.6||50.4||4.0 |- | 1965 | 596 000||48.4||48.2||3.5 |- | 1970 | 693 000||47.9||48.9||3.2 |- | 1975 | 822 000||47.1||50.1||2.8 |- | 1980 | 996 000||46.5||51.0||2.5 |- | 1985 |1 183 000||46.3||51.2||2.4 |- | 1990 |1 382 000||44.8||52.6||2.6 |- | 1995 |1 586 000||41.6||55.7||2.7 |- | 2000 |1 758 000||37.9||59.0||3.0 |- | 2005 |1 876 000||34.9||61.6||3.5 |- | 2010 |2 007 000||32.6||63.4||4.0 |}

==Ethnic groups== :[[Tswana people|Tswana or Setswana]] <ref name="CIATONGA">{{cite web|url= https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bc.html|title= Africa :: BOTSWANA|publisher= CIA The World Factbook}}</ref> 79%, [[BaKalanga|Kalanga]]<ref name="CIATONGA"/> 11%, [[Basarwa]]<ref name="CIATONGA"/> 3%, other 7% (including [[Kgalagadi people|Kgalagadi]] and [[White Africans of European ancestry|White]]<ref name="CIATONGA"/> )
==Languages== {{Main article|Languages of Botswana}} :[[Setswana]] 77.3%, [[Sekalanga]] 7.4%, [[Sekgalagadi, seyeyi ]] 3.4%, [[English language|English]] (official) 2.8%, [[Zezuru language|Zezuru]]/[[Shona language|Shona]] 2%, [[Sesarwa language|Sesarwa]] 1.7%, [[Sembukushu]] 1.6%, [[Zimbabwean Ndebele language|Ndebele]] 1%, other 2.8% (2011 est.) <ref name="CIATONGA"/>
==Religions== {{main article|Religion in Botswana}} : [[Christianity|Christian]]<ref name="CIATONGA"/> 79.1%, [[Badimo]]<ref name="CIATONGA"/> 4.1%, Other 1.4% (includes [[Baha'i]],<ref name="CIATONGA"/> [[Hinduism|Hindu]],<ref name="CIATONGA"/> [[Islam]],<ref name="CIATONGA"/> [[Rastafarian]]<ref name="CIATONGA"/>), None<ref name="CIATONGA"/> 15.2%, Unspecified<ref name="CIATONGA"/> 0.3% (2011 est.)
== CIA World Factbook demographic statistics ==
The following demographic statistics are from the 2017 [[CIA World Factbook]].
===Population=== :2,214,858 (July 2017 est.)
===Population growth rate=== :1.55% (2017 est.)
===Birth rate=== :22.1 births/1,000 population (2017 est.)
===Death rate=== :9.6 deaths/1,000 population (2017 est.)
===Median age=== :total: 24.5 years :male: 23.5 years :female: 25.6 years (2017 est.)
===Net migration rate=== :3 migrant(s)/1,000 population (2009 est.) [https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bc.html] :''note'': there is an increasing flow of [[Zimbabweans in Botswana|Zimbabweans into Botswana]] and South Africa in search of better economic opportunities.
===Urbanization=== :Urban population: 69.4% of total population (2018) :Rate of urbanization: 2.87% annual rate of change (2015–20 est.)
===Sex ratio=== :at birth: 1.03 male(s)/female :under 15 years: 1.04 male(s)/female :15–64 years: 1.02 male(s)/female :65 years and over: 0.68 male(s)/female :total population: 1.01 male(s)/female (2011 est.)
===Life expectancy at birth=== :Total population: 63.3 years :Male: 61.2 years :Female: 65.5 years (2017 est.)
===HIV/AIDS=== {{main article|HIV/AIDS in Botswana}} :Adult prevalence rate: 22.8% (2017 est.) :People living with HIV/AIDS: 380,000 (2017 est.) :Deaths due to AIDS: 4,100 (2017 est.)
===Physicians density=== :0.38 physicians/1,000 population (2012)
===Hospital bed density=== :1.8 beds/1,000 population (2010)
===Obesity - adult prevalence rate=== :18.9% (2015)
===Major infectious diseases=== :Degree of risk: high :Food or waterborne diseases: bacterial diarrhea, hepatitis A, and typhoid fever :Vectorborne disease: malaria (2009)
===Nationality=== :Noun: Motswana (singular), Batswana (plural) :Adjective: Motswana (singular), Batswana (plural)
===Literacy=== :Definition: age 15 and over can read and write :Total population: 88.5% :Male: 88% :Female: 88.9% (2015 est.)
===Education expenditure=== :8.7% of total GDP (2007)

Government Chief Information Officer |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |parent_agency = |child1_agency =[[Archives New Zealand]] |child2_agency =[[New Zealand Lottery Grants Board]] |child3_agency =[[New Zealand Local Government Commission|Local Government Commission]] |child4_agency =[[National Library of New Zealand]] |child5_agency =[[New Zealand Office for the Community & Voluntary Sector|Office for the Community & Voluntary Sector]] |child6_agency =[[New Zealand Office of Ethnic Affairs|Office of Ethnic Affairs]] |website = {{URL|http://www.dia.govt.nz/}} |footnotes = |chief3_name=|chief3_position=|chief4_name=|chief4_position=|chief5_name=|chief5_position=|chief6_name=|chief6_position=|chief7_name=|chief7_position=|chief8_name=|chief8_position=|chief9_name=|chief9_position=|parent_department=}} The '''Department of Internal Affairs''' ('''DIA'''; [[Māori language|Māori]]: ''Te Tari Taiwhenua'') is the public service department of New Zealand charged with issuing [[New Zealand passport|passports]]; administering applications for [[New Zealand nationality law|citizenship]] and [[New Zealand Lottery Grants Board|lottery]] grants; enforcing [[Censorship in New Zealand|censorship]] and [[Gambling in New Zealand|gambling]] laws; registering [[births]], [[deaths]], [[marriages]] and [[Civil union in New Zealand|civil unions]]; supplying support services to [[Ministers of the Crown]]; and advising the [[Government of New Zealand|government]] on a range of relevant policies and issues, part of a number of functions performed by Internal Affairs. Other services provided by the Department include a translation service, publication of the [[New Zealand Gazette]] (the official newspaper of the New Zealand Government), a flag hire service, management of VIP visits to New Zealand, running the [[Lake Taupo]] harbourmaster's office (under a special agreement with the local [[iwi]]) and the administration of offshore islands. During the late 1990s both the [[National Library of New Zealand]] and [[Archives New Zealand]] were separated from the Department along with the [[Ministry for Culture and Heritage]]. On 25 March 2010, the former Minister of State Services [[Tony Ryall]] announced that the Library and Archives would be merged into the Department.{{cite web|url=http://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/state-sector-changes-improve-performance|title=beehive.govt.nz - State sector changes to improve performance|publisher=Beehive.govt.nz|accessdate=25 November 2014}} Library and Archives stakeholders expressed serious concerns about the changes proposed.{{cite web|url=http://www.aranz.org.nz/includes/download.aspx?ID=107780|title=Underpinning democracy: the future of Archives New Zealand : Press release|publisher=Aranz.org.nz|accessdate=25 November 2014}} On 1 February 2011, both were brought into the Department of Internal Affairs.{{cite web|url=http://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/minister-welcomes-state-sector-legislation|title=Minister welcomes State Sector legislation (press release)|author=Guy, Nathan|work=beehive.govt.nz|publisher=New Zealand Government|accessdate=30 May 2014}} ==History== The Department of Internal Affairs traces its roots back to the [[Colonial Secretary (New Zealand)|Colonial Secretary's Office]], which from the time New Zealand became a British [[colony]], in 1840, was responsible for almost all central Government duties. The Department was the first government department to be established in New Zealand, and it became the home for a diverse range of government functions providing services to New Zealanders and advice to Ministers of the Crown. Hence the title of [[Michael Bassett]]'s 1997 history of the department: ''The Mother of All Departments''. Many of these responsibilities were lost as new departments and ministries were formed. The office's name was changed to the Department of Internal Affairs from 19 November 1907. Change has continued to the present day, as new roles and functions have come into the Department and others have been transferred elsewhere.{{cite web|title=History of the Department|url=http://www.dia.govt.nz/About-Internal-Affairs---Department-structure---History-of-the-Department|publisher=The Department of Internal Affairs|accessdate=10 March 2015}} ==Related organisations== The Department of Internal Affairs includes the [[New Zealand Office of Ethnic Affairs|Office of Ethnic Affairs]], which provides information to ethnic communities and policy advice to the government and the [[New Zealand Local Government Commission|Local Government Commission]], which makes decisions on the structure and representation requirements of [[local government]]. The Department's present activities also include the implementation of recent dog control and local government legislation. The Department has responsibility for supporting the community and voluntary sector through the Office for the Community and Voluntary Sector. The Chief Executive of the Department of Internal Affairs is also the Government Chief Information Officer (GCIO), with responsibility for developing and overseeing the government's ICT (Information, Communications and Technology) strategy and providing strategic advice on related matters. The Department also includes the National Library of New Zealand, Te Puna Māturanga o Aotearoa and Archives New Zealand, Te Rua Mahara o te Kāwanatanga. These two organisations were integrated into the Department on 1 February 2011 The Department provides secretariat support for several entities including: * The Gambling Commission * The Local Government Commission * Commissions of Inquiry and ad hoc bodies such as the Royal Commission on the Pike River Coal Mine tragedy and the Canterbury Earthquakes Royal Commission. * The Library and Information Advisory Commission, Ngā Kaiwhakamārama i ngā Kohikohinga Kōrero * The Public Lending Right Advisory Group * The Guardians Kaitiaki of the Alexander Turnbull Library * The Archives Council * The [[Film and Literature Board of Review]] * The Confidential Listening and Assistance Service == Ministers == The Department serves 6 portfolios, 7 ministers and a parliamentary under-secretary.{{cite web|url=http://beehive.govt.nz/sites/all/files/New-Ministerial-List.pdf|format=PDF|title=Ministerial List for Announcement on 6 October 2014|publisher=Beehive.govt.nz|accessdate=25 November 2014}}

[...] The changes take effect from 28 January. }} | rowspan="2" | [[File:Peter Dunne.jpg|75px]] | rowspan="2" | 2014 | rowspan="2" | 26 October 2017 |- ! style="border-top:solid 0 grey; background:{{United Future/meta/color}}"| | style="background:{{New Zealand National Party/meta/color}}"| | [[Bill English|English]] |- ! style="background:{{New Zealand First/meta/color}}"| ! 35 | [[Tracey Martin]] | [[File:Tracey Martin, 2017.jpg|75px]] | 26 October 2017 | present | style="background:{{New Zealand Labour Party/meta/color}}"| | [[Jacinda Ardern|Ardern]] |} ==Invitation to Present Commercial Opportunities== An ''invitation to present commercial opportunities'' (IPCO) is a process designed by the department to invite the [[private sector]] to present ideas for commercial relationships with government in relation to services already built/created by the government agency. The commercial relationships can include a [[public-private partnership]] or other arrangement between the private sector and the government to further develop, fund, innovate, distribute, and ensure uptake and use of the services.{{cite web|url=http://www.dia.govt.nz/press.nsf/d77da9b523f12931cc256ac5000d19b6/f77598fd51b36124cc25761f00048f3e!OpenDocument|title=Government explores private sector interest in online igovt services|date=27 August 2009|publisher=Department of Internal Affairs|accessdate=11 April 2012}} An IPCO is issued where a government is seeking options that provide it access to private sector specialised expertise, innovative ideas, and funding and the sharing of risk. Extending the reach of the services, while building on the benefits of established branding and related [[market penetration]] are also important. An IPCO is not a [[procurement]] process for goods or services, and it does not signal whether any final decision has been made on any future procurement process or any other action will be taken by government. It is intended to enable government to gauge whether there are organisations interested in, and what options are available for, public-private partnerships or other commercial arrangements to use and/or further develop, fund, innovate, distribute, and ensure uptake and use of a [[government agency]]’s services by the public, government agencies and the private sector. The IPCO process was developed in August 2009 to assist with collecting information from the private sector to use in advising government on future development and funding options for particular services. The IPCO has been used for two electronic identity services the New Zealand Government has built for government use to provide identity dependent services online. The two services are called the igovt logon service and the igovt identity verification service (igovt services). Government directed the Department of Internal Affairs to invite the market to provide written responses about whether private sector organisations were interested in: * using the igovt services if available to them, and * entering into public-private partnerships or other arrangements for the further development, funding, innovation, distribution, and ensuring uptake and use of the igovt services. ==See also== * [[New Zealand Birth Certificate]] * [[Censorship in New Zealand]] * [[Gambling in New Zealand]] * [[Five Nations Passport Group]] ==Bibliography== * [[Michael Bassett|Bassett, Michael]] ''The Mother of All Departments'' (1997, Auckland University Press, Auckland) {{ISBN|1-86940-175-1}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.dia.govt.nz/}} * [http://www.lgc.govt.nz/ Local Government Commission] * [http://www.civildefence.govt.nz/ Ministry of Civil Defence] * [http://www.ethnicaffairs.govt.nz/ Office of Ethnic Affairs] {{NZ Public Service Departments}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Department Of Internal Affairs (New Zealand)}} [[Category:New Zealand Public Service departments|Internal affairs]] [[Category:New Zealand society]] [[Category:Internal affairs ministries|New Zealand]] [[Category:Ministries established in 1840]] [[Category:1840 establishments in New Zealand]]

{{Feminism sidebar |concepts}}
The [[feminist movement]] has effected change in Western society, including [[women's suffrage]]; greater access to education; more equitable pay with men; the right to initiate divorce proceedings; the right of women to make individual decisions regarding pregnancy (including access to [[contraceptive]]s and [[abortion]]); and the right to own property.<ref name="Butler2">{{Cite journal | last = Butler | first = Judith | author-link = Judith Butler | title = Feminism by any other name (Judith Butler interviews Rosi Braidotti) | journal = [[Differences (journal)|differences: A Journal of Feminist Cultural Studies]] | volume = 6 | issue = 2–3 | pages = 272–361 | publisher = [[Duke University Press]] | date = Summer 1994 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref><ref name="Messer-Davidow">{{cite book | last = Messer-Davidow | first = Ellen | title = Disciplining feminism: from social activism to academic discourse | publisher = Duke University Press | location = Durham, [[North Carolina]] | year = 2002 | isbn = 9780822328438 }}</ref> Harvard Psychology Professor Steven Pinker argues that feminism has reduced domestic violence, especially against men as their likelihood of being killed by a female intimate partner has decreased six-fold.<ref>{{cite news | last = Pynchon | first = Victoria | title = Women's economic power decreases domestic violence against both genders | url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/shenegotiates/2011/12/05/womens-economic-power-decreases-domestic-violence-against-both-genders/ | work = [[Forbes]] | publisher = Forbes, Inc. | date = December 5, 2011 | access-date = February 4, 2012 }}</ref>
== Women's rights == [[File:Woman suffrage headquarters Cleveland.jpg|thumb|Woman Suffrage Headquarters, Cleveland, 1912]]
From the 1960s on, the [[women's liberation movement]] campaigned for [[women's rights]], including the same pay as men, equal rights in law, and the freedom to plan their families. Their efforts were met with mixed results.<ref>{{citation | last = Freeman | first = Jo | author-link = Jo Freeman | contribution = From suffrage to women's liberation: feminism in twentieth century America | editor-last = Freeman | editor-first = Jo | editor-link = Jo Freeman | title = Women: a feminist perspective| pages = 509–528 | publisher = Mayfield Pub. Co | location = Mountain View, California | year = 1995 | edition = 5th | isbn = 9781559341110 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [http://www.jofreeman.com/feminism/suffrage.htm View online.]</ref> Issues commonly associated with notions of women's rights include, though are not limited to, the right to bodily integrity and autonomy; to vote (universal suffrage); to hold public office; to work; to fair wages or [[Equal pay for women|equal pay]]; to own property; to education; to serve in the military; to enter into legal contracts; and to have marital, parental, and religious rights.<ref name="quarterly">{{cite book | last = Lockwood | first = Bert B. | title = Women's rights: a human rights quarterly reader | publisher = Johns Hopkins University Press | location = Baltimore | year = 2006 | isbn = 9780801883743 }}</ref> Feminists have worked to protect women and girls from [[child sexual abuse]],<ref>{{citation | last1 = Reavey | first1 = Paula | last2 = Warner | first2 = Sam | contribution = Introduction | editor-last1 = Reavey | editor-first1 = Paula | editor-last2 = Warner | editor-first2 = Sam | title = New feminist stories of child sexual abuse: sexual scripts and dangerous dialogues | page = 2 | publisher = New York Routledge | location = London | year = 2003 | isbn = 9780415259446 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=obHkvCPnos0C&pg=PA2 Preview.]</ref><ref>{{citation | last = Valentich | first = Mary | contribution = Feminist theory and social work practice (child sexual abuse) | editor-last = Turner | editor-first = Francis J. | title = Social work treatment: interlocking theoretical approaches | page = 215 | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = New York | year = 2011 | isbn = 9780195394658 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=x_k8Aptn6tEC&pg=PA215 Preview.]</ref><ref>{{citation | last = Jeffreys | first = Sheila | author-link = Sheila Jeffreys | contribution = 'Henpecking': women's campaigns to gain legislation against the sexual abuse of girls | editor-last = Jeffreys | editor-first = Sheila | editor-link = Sheila Jeffreys | title = The spinster and her enemies: feminism and sexuality, 1880–1930 | page = 84 | publisher = Spinifex | location = North Melbourne, Victoria | year = 1997 | isbn = 9781875559633 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=V0m96bhnEwYC&pg=PA84 Preview.]</ref><ref>{{citation | last = Olafson | first = Erna | contribution = Child sexual abuse | editor-last = Cling | editor-first = B.J. | title = Sexualized violence against women and children: a psychology and law perspective | page = 177 | publisher = Guilford Press | location = New York | year = 2004 | isbn = 9781593850616 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> challenging the prior belief that girls caused men to have sex with them even when the girls were very young.<ref>{{cite book | last = Rush | first = Florence | author-link = Florence Rush | title = The best kept secret: sexual abuse of children | publisher = Prentice-Hall | location = Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey | year = 1980 | isbn = 9780130747815 }}</ref>
In the [[United Kingdom|UK]], a public groundswell of opinion in favour of legal equality gained pace,{{When|date=September 2009}} including during the [[Women's rights#Modern movements|modern movement]], partly through the extensive employment of women in men's traditional roles during both world wars. By the 1960s, the legislative process was being readied, tracing through MP [[Willie Hamilton]]'s [[Select Committee (Westminster System)|select committee]] report, his Equal Pay for Equal Work Bill, the creation of a Sex Discrimination Board, Lady Sear's draft sex anti-discrimination bill, and a government [[Green Paper]] of 1973, until 1975 when the first British Sex Discrimination Act, an [[Equal Pay Act 1970|Equal Pay Act]], and an [[Equal Opportunities Commission (United Kingdom)|Equal Opportunities Commission]] came into force.<ref>{{cite news | last = Mackie | first = Lindsay | title = The equal pay day is here: Lindsay Mackie looks at the new laws aimed at boosting women's status | url = http://search.proquest.com/hnpguardianobserver/docview/185773278/3FED2E4525A34ECEPQ/7 | work = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = [[Guardian Media Group]] | page = 5 | subscription = yes | date = 29 December 1975 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Sex discrimination in advertising banned | work = [[The Times]] | publisher = [[News UK]] | date = 29 December 1975 }}</ref> With encouragement from the UK government, the other countries of the [[EEC]] soon followed suit with an agreement to ensure that discriminatory laws would be phased out across the European Community.
In the [[United States|U.S.]], the [[National Organization for Women]] ([[National Organization for Women|NOW]]) was created in 1966 with the purpose of bringing about equality for all women. NOW was one important group that fought for the [[Equal Rights Amendment]] ([[Equal Rights Amendment|ERA]]). This amendment stated that "equality of rights under the law shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or any state on account of sex."<ref>{{Cite web |title=The National Organization for Women's 1966 Statement of Purpose | url = http://now.org/about/history/statement-of-purpose/ | publisher = [[National Organization for Women]] }} [http://now.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Statement-of-Purpose.pdf Pdf.]</ref> But there was disagreement on how the proposed amendment would be understood. Supporters believed it would guarantee women equal treatment. But critics feared it might deny women the right be financially supported by their husbands. It died in 1982 because not enough states had ratified it. ERAs have been introduced in subsequent Congresses, but have failed to be passed.<ref>{{Cite web |title=National Organization for Women: Definition |url=http://www.answers.com/topic/national-organization-for-women?cat=biz-fin&nr=1 | website = answers.com | publisher = [[Answers.com]] }}</ref> Nonetheless, various laws advancing women's rights were promulgated, although many issues remained to be resolved.
In the final three decades of the 20th century, Western women knew a new freedom through [[birth control]], which enabled women to plan their adult lives, often making way for both career and family. The movement had been started in the 1910s by U.S. pioneering social reformer [[Margaret Sanger]] and in the UK and internationally by [[Marie Stopes]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Margaret Sanger |url=http://www.u-s-history.com/pages/h1676.html | website = u-s-history.com | publisher = US History.com }}</ref>
Publication of data and advocacy relevant to rights increased in recent decades. For example, the ''United Nations Human Development Report 2004'' estimated that, when both paid employment and unpaid household tasks are accounted for, on average women work more than men. In rural areas of selected developing countries women performed an average of 20 percent more work than men, or an additional 102 minutes per day. In the [[OECD]] countries surveyed, on average women performed 5 percent more work than men, or 20 minutes per day when both paid employment and unpaid household tasks are taken into account.<ref>{{citation | contribution = Section 28: Gender, Work Burden, and Time Allocation |url=http://hdr.undp.org/en/media/hdr04_complete.pdf |title= United Nations Human Development Report 2004 | page = 233 | format = PDF | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
== International law ==
=== CEDAW === The ''[[Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women]]'' ([[Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women|CEDAW]]) is an international convention adopted by the [[United Nations]] [[United Nations General Assembly|General Assembly]]. Described as an international [[bill of rights]] for women, it came into force on 3 September 1981.<ref>{{Cite web| title = Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women New York, 18 December 1979 | url = http://www.ohchr.org/EN/ProfessionalInterest/Pages/CEDAW.aspx |publisher=Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights|accessdate=September 6, 2009}}</ref> Several countries have ratified the Convention subject to certain declarations, reservations, and objections.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Declarations, Reservations and Objections to CEDAW|url=https://www.un.org/womenwatch/daw/cedaw/reservations-country.htm |publisher=United Nations Division for the Advancement of Women|accessdate=September 6, 2009}}</ref> [[Iran]], [[Sudan]], [[Somalia]], [[Qatar]], [[Nauru]], [[Palau]], [[Tonga]], and the United States have not ratified CEDAW.<ref name="Simpson">{{Cite news |author=Simpson, Peggy |date=March 30, 2009 |title=Chances Improve for Ratification of CEDAW |url=http://www.womensmediacenter.com/ex/033009.html |publisher=Women's Media Center |accessdate=September 7, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090406105638/http://www.womensmediacenter.com/ex/033009.html |archivedate=April 6, 2009 |df= }}</ref> Expecting a [[United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations|U.S. Senate]] vote,<ref name="Simpson" /> NOW has encouraged [[Barack Obama|President Obama]] to remove U.S. reservations and objections added in 2002<ref name="Simpson" /> before the vote.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Women need a strong CEDAW, not one with disabling RDUs|url=http://capwiz.com/now/issues/alert/?alertid=13970771 |publisher=National Organization for Women (capwiz.com)|accessdate=September 6, 2009|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20131010145456/http://www.now.org/lists/now-action-list/msg00395.html | archive-date = October 10, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Don't Be Deceived: Only a 'Clean' CEDAW Should Be Ratified |url=http://www.nowfoundation.org/issues/global/083109cedaw.html |date=August 31, 2009 |publisher=National Organization for Women Foundation |accessdate=September 7, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090910064523/http://www.nowfoundation.org/issues/global/083109cedaw.html |archivedate=September 10, 2009 |df= }}</ref> The CEDAW does not protect men from any form of discrimination.
== Reproductive rights == In the U.S., a major focus of political activism has centered on [[reproductive rights]], including for (and, among opponents, against) the decision by the U.S. [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] in the case of [[Roe v. Wade|''Roe'' v. ''Wade'']] enunciating a [[United States Constitution|Constitutional]] right for a woman to choose whether to carry a pregnancy to term.
== Gender-neutral language == [[Gender neutrality in English|Gender-neutral English]] is a description of [[Word usage|language usages]] which do not recognize gender and are aimed at minimizing assumptions regarding the biological [[sex]] of human [[reference|referents]]. The advocacy of gender-neutral language reflects, at least, two different agendas: one to clarify the ''inclusion'' of both sexes or genders (gender-inclusive language); the other that gender, as a category, is rarely worth marking in language (gender-neutral language). Gender-neutral language is sometimes described as ''non-sexist language'' by advocates and ''politically correct language'' by opponents.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usask.ca/policies/2_03.htm |title= University of Saskatchewan Policies 2001: Gender Neutral Language |accessdate=March 25, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061028110505/http://www.usask.ca/policies/2_03.htm |archivedate = October 28, 2006 | publisher = [[University of Saskatchewan]]}}</ref>
== Heterosexual family relationships == The increased entry of women into the workplace beginning in the twentieth century has affected gender roles and the [[division of labor]] within [[household]]s. Sociologist [[Arlie Russell Hochschild]] in ''The Second Shift'' and ''The Time Bind'' presented evidence that, in two-career couples, men and women, on average, spend about equal amounts of time working, but women still spend more time on housework.<ref name="Hochschild1">{{Cite book| last1 = Russell Hochschild | first1 = Arlie | last2 = Machung | first2 = Anne | author-link1 = Arlie Russell Hochschild | title = [[The Second Shift|The second shift: working families and the revolution at home]] | publisher = Penguin Books | location = New York | year = 2003 }} {{ISBN|9780142002926}}</ref><ref name="Hochschild2">{{cite book | last = Russell Hochschild | first = Arlie | author-link = Arlie Russell Hochschild | title = [[Time bind|The time bind: when work becomes home and home becomes work]] | publisher = Henry Holt & Co. | location = New York | year = 2001 }} {{ISBN|9780805066432}}</ref> Feminist writer [[Cathy Young]] responds to Hochschild's assertions by arguing that, in some cases, women may prevent the equal participation of men in housework and parenting.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Young | first = Cathy | authorlink = Cathy Young | title = The Mama Lion at the Gate | url = http://www.salon.com/2000/06/12/gatekeeping/ | date = June 12, 2000 | accessdate = July 8, 2008 | website = Salon.com | publisher = [[Salon (website)|Salon]] }}</ref> [[File:Anna Fischer-Dueckelmann - Die Frau als Hausaerztin.jpg|thumb|left|"The Woman as Family Doctor," traditional form of [[home care]]]] Feminist criticisms of men's contributions to child care and domestic labor in the Western middle class are typically centered on the idea that it is unfair for women to be expected to perform more than half of a household's domestic work and child care when both members of the relationship also work outside the home. Several studies provide statistical evidence that the financial income of married men does not affect their rate of attending to household duties.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = South | first1 = Scott J. | last2 = Spitze | first2 = Gelnna | title = Housework in marital and nonmarital households | journal = [[American Sociological Review]] | volume = 59 | issue = 3 | pages = 327–348 | publisher = [[Sage Publications|Sage]] | jstor = 2095937 | doi = 10.2307/2095937 | date = June 1994 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.2307/2095937 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref><ref>{{citation | last1 = Fenstermaker Berk | first1 =Sarah | last2 = Shih | first2 = Anthony |contribution=Contributions to household labour: comparing wives' and husbands' reports |series=SAGE Yearbooks on Women and Politics Series |title=Women and household labour |year=1980 |editor-last=Fenstermaker Berk | editor-first =Sarah |publisher=[[Sage Publications|Sage]] |location=Beverly Hills, California | isbn = 9780803912113 }}</ref>
In ''Dubious Conceptions'', [[Kristin Luker]] discusses the effect of feminism on teenage women's choices to bear children, both in and out of wedlock. She says that, as childbearing out of wedlock has become more socially acceptable, young women, especially poor young women, while not bearing children at a higher rate than in the 1950s, now see less of a reason to get married before having children. Her explanation for this is that the economic prospects for poor men are slim, hence poor women have a low chance of finding a husband who will be able to provide reliable financial support.<ref name="Luker">{{cite book | last = Luker | first = Kristin | author-link = Kristin Luker | title = Dubious conceptions: the politics of teenage pregnancy | publisher = Harvard University Press | location = Cambridge, Massachusetts | year = 1996 | isbn = 9780674217034 }}</ref>
Although research suggests that, to an extent, both women and men perceive feminism to be in conflict with romance, studies of undergraduates and older adults have shown that feminism has positive impacts on relationship health for women and sexual satisfaction for men, and found no support for negative stereotypes of feminists.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Rudman | first1 = Laurie A. | last2 = Phelan | first2 = Julie E. | author-link1 = Laurie A. Rudman | title = The interpersonal power of feminism: is feminism good for romantic relationships? | journal = [[Sex Roles (journal)|Sex Roles]] | volume = 57 | issue = 11 | pages = 787–799| publisher = [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] | doi = 10.1007/s11199-007-9319-9 | date = December 2007 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s11199-007-9319-9 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [http://rutgerssocialcognitionlab.weebly.com/uploads/1/3/9/7/13979590/rudmanphelan2007sr.pdf Pdf.]</ref>
== Religion == [[Feminist theology]] reconsiders the traditions, practices, [[sacred text|text]]s, and theologies of religions from a feminist perspective.<ref name="Parsons_S">{{Cite book | last=Parsons | first=Susan Frank | authorlink=Susan Frank Parsons | title=The Cambridge companion to feminist theology | year=2002 | publisher=Cambridge University Press | location=Cambridge, UK | isbn=9780521663809 | pages=}}</ref><ref name="Loades_A">{{Cite book | last1 = Loades | first1 = Ann | last2 = Armstong | first2 = Karen | author-link2 = Karen Armstrong | title=Feminist theology: a reader | year=1990 | publisher=SPCK | location=London | isbn=9780664251291 }}</ref><ref name=Watson>{{Cite book | last=Watson | first=Natalie K. | authorlink=Natalie K. Watson | title=Feminist theology | year=2003 | publisher=W.B. Eerdmans Publishing Co. | location=Grand Rapids, Michigan | isbn=9780802848284 | pages=}}</ref> Its goals include increasing the role of women among the clergy and religious authorities, reinterpreting male-dominated imagery and language about the [[God and gender (disambiguation)|deity or deities]], determining women's place in relation to career and motherhood, and studying images of women in the religion's sacred texts.<ref name=Parsons_S /><ref name=Loades_A /><ref name="Bundesen">{{cite book | last = Bundesen | first = Lynne | title = The feminine spirit: recapturing the heart of Scripture: the woman's guide to the Bible | publisher = Jossey-Bass | location = San Francisco | year = 2007 | isbn = 9780787984953 }}</ref> [[Difference feminism]] offers compatibility with gender-differentiating teachings of many major theologies, although difference feminism, when essentialist, is itself controversial.
[[Christian feminism]] is a branch of feminist theology which seeks to interpret and understand [[Christianity]] in light of the equality of women and men. Because this equality has been historically ignored, Christian feminists believe their contributions are necessary for a complete understanding of Christianity. While there is no standard set of beliefs among Christian feminists, most agree that God does not discriminate on the basis of biologically determined characteristics such as sex. Their major issues are the [[ordination of women]], male dominance in Christian marriage, and claims of moral deficiency and inferiority of abilities of women compared to men. They also are concerned with the balance of parenting between mothers and fathers and the overall treatment of women in the church.<ref name="Haddad">{{Cite journal | last = Haddad | first = Mimi | title = Egalitarian pioneers: Betty Friedan or Catherine Booth? | journal = Priscilla Papers | volume = 20 | issue = 4 | pages = 53–59 | publisher = [[Christians for Biblical Equality]] | date = Autumn 2006 | url = http://www2.cbeinternational.org/CBE_InfoPack/pdf_files/haddad_egalitarian_pioneers.pdf | format = pdf | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref><ref name="anderson">{{cite book | last1 = Anderson | first1 = Pamela Sue | last2 = Clack | first2 = Beverley | author-link = Pamela Sue Anderson | title = Feminist philosophy of religion: critical readings | publisher = Routledge | location = London New York | year = 2004 | isbn = 9780415257503 }}</ref> [[New feminism]] is a branch of difference feminism situated within Catholicism.
[[Islamic feminism]] is concerned with the role of [[Women and Islam|women in Islam]] and aims for the full equality of all [[Muslims]], regardless of gender, in public and private life. Islamic feminists advocate [[women's rights]], [[gender equality]], and social justice grounded in an Islamic framework. Although rooted in Islam, the movement's pioneers have also utilized secular and Western feminist discourses and recognize the role of Islamic feminism as part of an integrated global feminist movement.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.feminismeislamic.org/eng/index.htm |publisher=feminismeislamic.org |author=Catalan Islamic Board |title=II International Congress on Islamic Feminism|accessdate=9 July 2008 |date=24–27 October 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080321140633/http://www.feminismeislamic.org/eng/index.htm |archivedate = 21 March 2008}}</ref> Advocates of the movement seek to highlight the deeply rooted teachings of equality in the [[Quran]] and encourage a questioning of the patriarchal interpretation of Islamic teaching through the Quran, ''[[hadith]]'' (sayings of [[Muhammad]]), and ''[[sharia]]'' (law) towards the creation of a more equal and just society.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Badran | first = Margot | url = http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2002/569/cu1.htm | title = Al-Ahram Weekly: Islamic Feminism: What's in a Name? | accessdate = 9 July 2008 | date = 17–23 January 2002 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150320074746/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2002/569/cu1.htm | archivedate = 20 March 2015 | df = }}</ref>
[[Jewish feminism]] is a movement that seeks to improve the religious, legal, and social status of women within [[Judaism]] and to open up new opportunities for religious experience and leadership for Jewish women. Feminist movements, with varying approaches and successes, have opened up within all major branches of Judaism. In its modern form, the movement can be traced to the early 1970s in the United States. According to [[Judith Plaskow]], who has focused on feminism in [[Reform Judaism]], the main issues for early Jewish feminists in these movements were the exclusion from the all-male prayer group or ''[[minyan]]'', the exemption from positive time-bound ''[[Mitzvah|mitzvot]]'', and women's inability to function as witnesses and to initiate [[Jewish view of marriage#Divorce|divorce]].<ref name="Plaskow1997">{{citation |last=Plaskow | first =Judith | author-link = Judith Plaskow |contribution=Jewish feminist thought |editor-last1=Frank | editor-first1 = Daniel H. |editor-last2 = Leaman | editor-first2 = Oliver | editor-link2 = Oliver Leaman |title=History of Jewish philosophy |year=2003 |publisher=Routledge |location=London |isbn=9780415324694 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
The [[Dianic Wicca]] or Wiccan feminism is a female-focused and [[Goddess movement|Goddess]]-centered Wiccan faith that is also known as a feminist religion that teaches witchcraft as every woman's right. It is also one faith of the many practiced in [[Wicca]].<ref>{{citation |last=Raphael | first = Melissa | contribution = Chapter ^: Feminist Witchcraft | editor-last=Raphael | editor-first = Melissa |title=Introducing Thealogy: discourse on the Goddess |year=1999 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=9781850759751}}</ref>
[[Atheist feminism]] advocates the [[feminism|equality of men and women]] within atheism.<ref>{{cite news | last = Clare |first = Amy | title = Sexism in the atheist community: not rational, not reasonable, not funny | url = http://www.thefword.org.uk/blog/2010/03/sexism_in_the_a | work = [[The F-Word (feminist blog)|The F-Word]] | date = 3 March 2010 }}</ref> Atheist feminists also oppose [[religion]], being a major source of female oppression and inequality, believing that all religions are sexist and oppressive to women.<ref>{{cite news | last = Hari |first = Johann | author-link = Johann Hari | title = Does God hate women? | url = http://www.newstatesman.com/books/2009/07/women-god-stangroom-benson | work = [[New Statesman]] | publisher = Progressive Media International | date = 2 July 2009 }}</ref>
=== Theology === [[Feminist theology]], sometimes referred to as the [[Goddess movement]], is a movement found in several religions to reconsider the traditions, practices, [[scripture]]s, and [[theology|theologies]] of those religions from a feminist perspective.<ref name=Parsons_S /><ref name=Loades_A /><ref name=Watson /> Some of the goals of feminist theology include increasing the role of women among the [[clergy]] and religious authorities, reinterpreting male-dominated imagery and language about [[God|the deity or deities]], determining women's place in relation to [[career]] and [[motherhood]], and studying images of women in the religion's [[sacred texts]].<ref name=Parsons_S /><ref name=Loades_A /> In [[Wicca]], "the Goddess" is a deity of prime importance, along with her consort the [[Horned God]]. In the earliest Wiccan publications, she is described as a tribal goddess of the witch community, neither omnipotent nor universal, and it was recognised that there was a greater "[[Cosmological argument|Prime Mover]]", although the witches did not concern themselves much with this being.<ref>{{citation | first = Gerald B. | last = Gardner | authorlink = Gerald Gardner (Wiccan) | contribution = Witches' memories and beliefs | editor-first = Gerald B. | editor-last = Gardner | editor-link = Gerald Gardner (Wiccan) | title = The meaning of witchcraft |pages=26–27 | publisher = Copple House Books | location = Lakemont, Georgia | year = 1988 | origyear = 1959 | isbn = 9780939708024 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|2}}

50,414 | popplace = {{flag|Lombardy}}, {{flag|Emilia-Romagna}}, {{flag|Veneto}}, {{flag|Sicily}} | langs = [[Italian language|Italian]], [[English language|English]] | rels = Mainly [[Roman Catholicism]], [[Protestantism]] | related = [[Ghanaian people|Ghanaians]] }} The presence of '''Ghanaians in Italy''' dates back to the 1980s. ==Numbers== In 2010 in [[Italy]] there are 46,890 regular immigrants from [[Ghana]]. In 2006 there were 36,540. The three cities with most number of Ghanaians are: [[Palermo]], [[Modena]] and [[Reggio Emilia]].{{cite news|url=http://www.comuni-italiani.it/statistiche/stranieri/gh.html|title= Comuni Italiani|}} ==History== [[File:MBalotelli Nazionale.jpg|thumb|left|The footballer [[Mario Balotelli]] an Italian of [[Ghanaian people|Ghanaian]] descent]] In Italy the migration from Ghana began in the mid-1980s, when people came over as students driven by economic motives. The choice of Italy as a place of destination, it is often due to the ease of obtaining an entry visa, and the difficulty of obtaining an entry permit for other European countries. In fact initially the preferred destinations are Britain, then Germany and the United States, but many of them, the first citation is available and has been for Italy. Towards the year 1988 also was easier to get a visa for Italy because there were few immigrants, but Britain was more rigid because many Ghanaians actually entered as tourists stayed permanently. The guys of the second generation who were born in Italy, studying, trying to carve out a space, to achieve a respectable economic independence and parents work very hard to guarantee them a relative stability. ==Entrepreneurship== ''Ghanacoop'' was born in [[Modena]] in 2005 within the National Association of [[Ghana]] and it is one of the first non-profit social enterprises run by immigrants on the Italian territory. It's a concrete example of community enterprise, involving an entire community as a whole of its economic activities, social or cultural. The farm, which involves 135 workers cultivating an area of 400 hectares, exports its products to the British market and, through Ghanacoop, on the Italian market. On the local market the product is sold to both distributors of fresh produce, and for firms engaged in processing for the production of juices, fruit concentrates and fruit cut, or, in the Italian business vocabulary, fourth range.{{cite news |title=GhanaCoop |url=http://www.migrantiebanche.it/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=106:imprenditoria-migrante-un-esempio-per-tuttiecco-a-voi-ghanacoop&catid=45:imprenditoria-migrante&Itemid=12 |year=2007 |location=Modena |first= |last= |accessdate=1 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090703195332/http://www.migrantiebanche.it/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=106%3Aimprenditoria-migrante-un-esempio-per-tuttiecco-a-voi-ghanacoop&catid=45%3Aimprenditoria-migrante&Itemid=12 |archivedate=3 July 2009 |df= }} ==Notable Ghanaians in Italy== [[File:Mario Balotelli Euro 2012 Training.jpg|thumb|[[Mario Balotelli]]]] *[[Gloria Hooper (athlete)|Gloria Hooper]], (1992) athlete *[[Mario Balotelli]], (1990) footballer *[[Giovanni Kyeremateng]], (1991) footballer *[[Desmond N'Ze]], (1989) footballer *[[Kingsley Boateng]], (1994) footballer ==References== {{reflist}} {{Ghanaian diaspora}} {{Immigration to Italy}} [[Category:African diaspora in Italy]] [[Category:History of Ghana]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Italy]]
